data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9ba0e6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Among the recent campaign contributions to Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias from Perry Mandera and businesses affiliated with him." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9ba0e6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/29dc857/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9ba0e6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Among the recent campaign contributions to Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias from Perry Mandera and businesses affiliated with him.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Illinois State Board of Elections</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Mandera’s Custom Companies has also contributed money to a trade group representing the trucking industry that in turn has given campaign money to Giannoulias, whose agency licenses and regulates truckers in Illinois. The group previously gave to White’s campaign.</p><p>Mandera’s business portfolio has also included an interest in legalized marijuana, starting with medical weed and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cannabis/2019/12/3/20994147/perry-mandera-herbal-care-center-marijuana-recreational-weed-license" target="_blank" >eventually getting into recreational sales</a>.</p><p>Mandera and individuals and businesses affiliated with him have been prolific campaign givers over the years to a variety of other candidates and causes, from President Donald Trump, a Republican, to outgoing U.S. Rep. Jesus “Chuy” Garcia, an Illinois Democrat. Custom Companies gave more than $600,000 over the years to state and local campaigns, records show.</p><p>Mandera also has been a donor to charities that have included Loyola Academy, a Catholic high school in Wilmette.</p><p>Two decades ago while Giannoulias was running for Illinois treasurer, questions emerged about loans made by his family’s business, the now-shuttered Broadway Bank where he worked, to reputed crime figures.</p><p>Giannoulias initially defended one of the loans and the borrower — reputed mob figure Michael “Jaws” Giorango — in an interview with the Chicago Tribune. He later walked that back, telling the Chicago Sun-Times: “I should have taken more time to look at their background.”</p><p>"While we did our job as bankers to make sure that they were creditworthy borrowers and the value of the collateral was adequate, I probably should have looked into it more."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/01/29/lobbyist-john-kelly-possible-chicago-mayor-bid-brandon-johnson-ballys-white-sox-katten-muchin-election" target="_blank" >Veteran lobbyist with clients who regularly intersect with City Hall weighs run for Chicago mayor</a> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2024/07/19/dupage-county-states-attorney-bob-berlin-campaign-fundraiser-donation-palumbo-john-kelly" target="_blank" >Banned contractors participate in campaign fundraiser for DuPage County state’s attorney</a> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/01/16/suburban-strip-club-blackjacks-gentlemens-club-south-elgin-kane-county-liquor-commission-video-gambling" target="_blank" >Suburban strip club with sordid past wins back liquor license over objections by some locals</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Robert Herguth

entries.title: Mom says she killed in self-defense. Will jury agree?
entries.summary: <h3>Good morning, Chicago. ✶</h3><p>🔎 <b>Below</b>: Keshia Golden says she fatally stabbed Calvin Sidney in 2022 when he attacked her after their baby shower. The mother of a 3-year-old still faces murder charges in a case her lawyers argue is self-defense.</p><p>🗞️ <b>Plus</b>: Reflecting on four years after Russia invaded Ukraine, a major campaign donor has reputed mob ties and more news you need to know.</p><p>📧 <b>Subscribe</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletter-hub.suntimes.com/" target="_blank" >Get this newsletter delivered to your inbox weekday mornings.</a></p><p>⏱️: <i>An 8-minute read</i></p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S WEATHER 🌥️</h4><p>Mostly cloudy with a chance of rain and a high near 41.</p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S TOP STORY " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e8b145e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Feb%2Fb72cc9c64fc3b2b761c9a53d1bf2%2Fdomestickilling-260224-12.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f92fe95/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Feb%2Fb72cc9c64fc3b2b761c9a53d1bf2%2Fdomestickilling-260224-12.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e8b145e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Feb%2Fb72cc9c64fc3b2b761c9a53d1bf2%2Fdomestickilling-260224-12.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Keshia Golden is claiming self-defense in the 2022 killing of her child’s father, Calvin Sidney.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-t/" target="_blank" >Woman says she killed abusive boyfriend to save herself and their unborn child — will jury agree?</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-i/" target="_blank" >Sophie Sherry</a></h5><p><b>Fatal stabbing</b>: Three and a half years ago, Keshia Golden thought her life was over — one way or another. Golden said that when her boyfriend threw her against a counter, she thought she and her unborn child were going to die. Then, after she fought back and fatally stabbed him, she thought she would spend the rest of her life behind bars, she said. </p><p><b>Her release</b>: Golden was eventually released from jail, thanks to a team of advocates and lawyers who rallied around her. She was able to give birth and raise her daughter on the outside. It has been "the best thing that ever happened" to her, Golden told the Sun-Times.</p><p><b>Pending trial</b>: Now she’s preparing for trial and is fearful that a jury won’t see her side of the story. Golden is due back in court next week. Her lawyers plan to argue she was acting in self-defense against a man with a history of abuse. But they’re pleading for the Cook County state’s attorney’s office to drop the case altogether.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-d/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>WAR IN UKRAINE 🇺🇦</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d00000" name="image-d00000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e15a9e5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fae%2F48%2Fe046a09a4b7889543bc3be8da186%2Fukraineanniversary-260224-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/47784b9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fae%2F48%2Fe046a09a4b7889543bc3be8da186%2Fukraineanniversary-260224-2.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a346352/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fae%2F48%2Fe046a09a4b7889543bc3be8da186%2Fukraineanniversary-260224-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Oksana Koledova, owner of a Ukrainian grocery store called Varenychok located at 4840 N. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-h/" target="_blank" >4 years after Russian invasion of Ukraine, area residents reflect</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-k/" target="_blank" >Violet Miller</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-u/" target="_blank" >Stephanie Zimmermann</a></h5><p><b>'Daily life'</b>: When Russia first invaded Ukraine in 2022, Oksana Koledova regularly checked in with her brother, who was fighting on the front lines, and with loved ones facing down bullets and bombs. Wounded two years ago, her brother now brings resources to fellow troops, and her father runs meals and supplies to soldiers. For Koledova, a Vernon Hills resident who moved to the U.S. 19 years ago, the fight for her home country is her "daily life."</p><p><b>Incalculable toll</b>: An estimated 1.8 million soldiers reportedly have been killed, wounded or gone missing on both sides. But that doesn’t include many who have returned from the battlefield with mental health struggles, Koledova said.</p><p><b>Seeking refuge</b>: Iryna Potishma is among some of the 5.9 million refugees who have fled the country as Russia continues to occupy Ukrainian territory. More than 40,000 Ukrainians have found new homes in the Chicago area. Potishma's loved ones back home have mostly been spared from the battle, though months ago, missiles struck a building near her brother’s apartment. Adapting to life in the U.S. has been her own struggle.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-o/" target="_blank" ><b>READ target="_blank" >Ex-strip club owner with reputed mob ties is big campaign donor to Alexi Giannoulias</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-n/" target="_blank" >Robert Herguth</a></h5><p><b>Donor history</b>: For years, businessman Perry Mandera ran a topless bar on the Near North Side, at times with help from reputed organized crime associates, including the late "mob cop" Fred Pascente. These days, Mandera, his family and their businesses are contributing heavily to the campaign fund benefitting Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias.</p><p><b>The haul</b>: With Giannoulias a potential candidate for Chicago mayor, companies affiliated with Mandera have contributed at least $80,000 to Citizens for Giannoulias since 2022. That’s the year Giannoulias won his current elected post. Beyond that, Mandera and his family have collectively given nearly $30,000 more over the last five years.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Pascente, a former Chicago cop known to associate with the late mobster Anthony Spilotro, was listed in a 1997 Chicago Crime Commission report as a known member or associate of organized crime. Pascente died in 2014, not long before his autobiography was released. Titled "Mob Cop: My Life of Crime in the Chicago Police Department," the book includes passages about Mandera.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-p/" Demolition is expected to take four to six weeks, the university said.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Constructed in 1926 by architect R. Bernard Kurzon, the 30-unit apartment building at 1224 W. Loyola Ave. was once home to businesses Archie’s Cafe, Roman Susan Gallery and Edge Art. It’s next to the Loyola Red Line stop.</p><p><b>What's next</b>: A spokesperson for Loyola has said the location is part of a future Chicago Transit Authority project, "meaning Loyola will not be the sole decisionmaker regarding its long-term use. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jy/" target="_blank" >Chris Casacchia</a></h5><p><b>Big bill</b>: The passage of President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending bill last year carries vast implications for Illinois taxpayers, with experts saying the wealthiest filers are likely to reap the most benefits.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: The so-called One Big Beautiful Bill Act was signed into law July 2025 and made permanent several provisions in Trump’s old Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which expired Dec. 31, 2025.</p><p><b>Overview</b>: The bill includes more than just tax cuts. It makes spending cuts to certain federal programs as well as boosts spending for some agencies. Overall, the megabill will upend household finances, but will also provide more clarity for financial planning, financial advisers have said.</p><p><b>Down to brass tax</b>: Find our breakdown of the bill's vast implications for Illinois taxpayers <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jj/" target="_blank" >here</a>.</p><p><b>From our tax guide</b>: <br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-742dbe73-118a-11f1-9503-0dbc8aae0681"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jt/" target="_blank" >What taxpayers need to know about savings plans, tax changes in 2026</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-ji/" target="_blank" >Strategies to consider if you’re looking to reduce capital gains taxes</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jd/" target="_blank" >How to avoid underpayment penalties by the IRS</a></li></ul><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jh/" target="_blank" ><b>MORE ON TAXES</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4> FROM THE PRESS BOX 🏈🏒🏀</h4><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-742de580-118a-11f1-9503-0dbc8aae0681"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jk/" target="_blank" ><b>NFL Scouting Combine</b></a>: Bears coach Ben Johnson and general manager Ryan Poles will meet the media Tuesday blocks from the Indiana statehouse. Billy Meilicke and his crew.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-ti/" target="_blank" >Icebreaker boat the James J. Versluis has been shattering lake since 1957</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-td/" target="_blank" >Stefano Esposito</a></h5><p>Before boarding the almost 70-year-old James J. Versluis, passengers get a life jacket and a set of ear plugs, because things can get "loud and crunchy."</p><p>As the Versluis sets off from its mooring at Navy Pier one morning in early February, the sound of its 126-ton steel hull shuddering through ice grates on the ear like a trash compactor chomping rocks.</p><p>"For the first couple of years, when you’re smacking up against ice, it’s really nerve-racking. You just feel like that ice is going to pop right through the hull," said Eddie Popelas, who served as the tugboat’s engineer from 2002 to 2013 and whose father was at one time the boat’s captain.</p><p>For Capt. Billy Meilicke and Marine Engineer Rich Frizelis — in charge of the tugboat on this morning — the noise is just part of the daily soundtrack that includes the thrum of the 850-horsepower diesel engine and the single blast of the foghorn.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-th/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>WATCH: ABOARD AN ICE entries.author: Matt Moore

entries.title: Bears GM Ryan Poles feels 'pretty good' on retaining some key players, noncommittal on others
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — As <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >the Bears</a> evaluate their options this offseason, some key players under contract aren’t necessarily certain to be back.</p><p>In addition to working through their own pending free agents, like starting safeties Kevin Byard and Jaquan Brisker, the Bears have affordable outs on the contracts of linebacker Tremaine Edmunds, tight end Cole Kmet and running back D’Andre Swift. They also could save salary-cap space by trading wide receiver DJ Moore.</p><p>For now, Kmet and Swift seem safe. The Combine has a way of speeding up trade talks throughout the league, which could open opportunities for the Bears that would require them to create extra cap space, but general manager Ryan Poles currently plans on those two being on the team this season.</p><p>“I feel pretty good about [them] being here, but again, there’s a lot more calls coming in on interest in some of these guys, so we have to sequence that out to see how it impacts our team,” Poles said Tuesday. “I’ve talked about cost of replacement, so what does that look like?</p><p>“We know what we need to do, but any new, unique opportunities that might pop up are usually going to pop up here, and then we’ll get back and sort it all out and make decisions, but I feel pretty good about those guys.”</p><p>Swift rushed for a career-high 1,087 yards and nine touchdowns last season and told the Sun-Times recently <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/16/bears-rb-dandre-swift-hopes-he-convinced-team-to-keep-him-heading-into-final-year-of-contract" >he hoped his performance was convincing enough to keep him with the Bears</a>. He’s set to count $8.8 million against the cap this season, the final one of his deal, though the Bears could cut him for a dead-cap hit of $1.3 million.</p><p>Kmet had a down year with just 30 catches for 347 yards and two touchdowns as the Bears incorporated first-round pick Colston Loveland into the offense. Kmet has two years, $23.2 million left on his contract with an out this offseason at $3.2 million.</p><p>Poles was noncommittal on the future of Edmunds and Moore. He sidestepped a question about releasing Edmunds, who would cost $17.4 million or could be released for $2.4 million, and spoke highly of Moore, saying he’s “happy with him” while leaving the door open for a trade.</p><p>“I’ve got to have conversations and see what is the best combination of players we can bring in,” Poles said. “We want him here. We think highly of him. He’s a great teammate. He’s been productive consistently over the last couple years.</p><p>“I have nothing but great things to say about him, but this is the time that you have to look at all the different scenarios and see what can allow us to put the best team out there. He’s a guy we want here, but we have to look at all different scenarios.”</p><p>Moore totaled 2,330 yards and 14 touchdown catches over his first two seasons with the Bears, but slipped to a career-low 50 catches for 682 yards last season.</p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Blackhawks prospect update: Gavin Hayes making himself relevant by emulating Zach Hyman
entries.summary: <p>Credit Will Moran, one of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a>' player development staffers, for possibly unlocking something new inside Hawks forward prospect Gavin Hayes.</p><p>During a video coaching session a few weeks ago, Moran pulled up clips of Oilers forward Zach Hyman that he thought Hayes might learn from.</p><p>"[Will showed me] how [Hyman] gets to the back post and grits it up in front of the net," Hayes said Sunday. "That threw that in my head, and obviously, it has worked out."</p><p>It has worked out in that Hayes has erupted on a goal-scoring tear for the AHL's Rockford IceHogs, racking up six goals in his last eight games and 15 points in 22 games since Christmas.</p><p>Considering the 2022 third-round pick had previously recorded only 22 points in 77 career AHL games since the start of last season, this represents a major surge in production.</p><p>As a result, Hayes has become slightly relevant again within the Hawks' crowded prospect pool. He will become even more relevant if he keeps this up for the rest of the season.</p><p>The possibility of him developing into a bottom-six NHL player with some scoring pop seems to be back on the table, albeit far from assured.</p><p>"Gavin [has] had a lot of opportunities," Rockford coach Jared Nightingale said. "They weren't going in for him, but he kept a really good attitude and showed up with the same mindset each day, wanting to get better. I'm happy for him. He's had all those chances, and now they're starting to go in."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">JUST 30 SECONDS INTO THE GAME⏱️ <a href="https://t.co/12IJKnbWYA">https://t.co/12IJKnbWYA</a> <a href="https://t.co/JuYmQPATvO">pic.twitter.com/JuYmQPATvO</a></p>— Rockford IceHogs (@goicehogs) <a href="https://twitter.com/goicehogs/status/2025378580578873493?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 22, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>Hayes earned his first pro hat trick Saturday against San Diego. After scoring two pretty goals off rushes in the first period, he capped it off with a scrappy goal from the low slot.</p><p>In the rematch Sunday, his confidence was noticeably high as he maneuvered assertively around the offensive zone and tapped his stick to call for the puck whenever he slipped open. He didn't score, but he did generate one Grade A chance with a nifty deflection in front of the net.</p><p>"Gavin is really smart about being in the right spots at the right times," Nightingale said.</p><p>His ice time has increased in accordance with his play. After starting the season on the fourth line, he has become a staple in Rockford's top six and power-play units, taking advantage of open roles in the lineup created by injuries and call-ups.</p><p>"It was a slow start, and then I got in a groove and started playing a little bit more and started shooting the puck a little bit more, and the confidence came with that," Hayes said. "Bounces started going my way."</p><p>He's listed at 6-1, but he looks taller than that in person, and his physicality has also increased markedly this season.</p><p>"[I'm] holding onto [the puck] a little bit more, making plays, because I can see the ice pretty well," he added.</p><p>Fellow Hawks forward prospect Marek Vanacker previously mentioned Hyman as a stylistic model of his, too, although that might be in part because Hyman's family now owns the OHL club, Brantford, that Vanacker (and previously Nick Lardis) plays for.</p><p>Still, there's no denying the fact Hyman has carved out quite a career as a complementary winger with a knack for burying goals around the net, somewhat similarly to Hawks forward Tyler Bertuzzi.</p><p>Realistically, Hayes probably won't become a 54-goal scorer in the NHL. But considering he's only 21 (turning 22 in May), he could have plenty of development ahead of him.</p><p>Looking back at the Hawks' <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2022/7/8/23200431/blackhawks-draft-picks-2022-nhl-paul-ludwinski-ryan-greene-gavin-hayes-samuel-savoie" target="_blank" >Day Two draft picks</a> in 2022, Ryan Greene has already established himself as an NHL player while Hayes has begun to pace ahead of Samuel Savoie, Aidan Thompson and Paul Ludwinski (who are all also in Rockford). Meanwhile, sixth-round pick Dominic James' NHL success with the Lightning is frustrating to witness from afar.</p>
entries.author: Ben Pope

entries.title: Durbin llevará a 'Dreamer' original al discurso del Estado de la Unión de Trump del martes
entries.summary: <p>El senador Dick Durbin llevará a la mujer de Chicago que lo inspiró a presentar la Ley DREAM hace 25 años al discurso anual del Estado de la Unión del presidente Donald Trump el martes, mientras que en cambio varios demócratas de Illinois planean no asistir.</p><p>Se unen a docenas de otros demócratas que dicen que no escucharán al presidente ofrecer su versión del estado de la nación tras un año de enérgicas campañas de deportación y recortes en el cuidado de la salud.</p><p>La senadora Tammy Duckworth, junto con los representantes federales Mike Quigley, Sean Casten, Delia Ramírez, Jan Schakowsky y Eric Sorensen, dicen que no asistirán al discurso anual, siendo Duckworth quien lo califica como “otro mitin de campaña lleno de mentiras”.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-3f0000" name="module-3f0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“Casi todos los días, este presidente y su administración les dicen a los estadounidenses que crean en una cosa mientras nosotros vemos algo diferente con nuestros propios ojos”, declaró Duckworth en un comunicado. “Todos estaríamos mejor si escucháramos los hechos, que son exactamente lo opuesto a lo que sale de su boca”.</p><p>Schakowsky comentó que sus electores han inundado su oficina con llamadas pidiéndole que se salte este discurso.</p><p>“No puedo, en buena conciencia, sentarme en esa cámara de representantes el martes por la noche y hacer como si todo fuera normal mientras familias en mi distrito viven con miedo constante de esta administración y luchan todos los días solo para mantener comida en la mesa y un techo”, dijo Schakowsky en un comunicado.</p><p>Ramírez se unirá a al menos 15 otros demócratas que asistirán a un evento de protesta en el National Mall llamado el “Estado de la Unión del Pueblo”. Quigley dijo que participará en una reunión virtual organizada por Indivisible Barrington en su lugar.</p><p>Durbin anunció el lunes que su invitada es Tereza Lee, pianista de concierto criada en el lado norte por inmigrantes coreanos, cuya historia de vida inspiró a Durbin a presentar la legislación que se conocería como la Ley DREAM o el DREAM Act.</p><p>La Ley de Desarrollo, Alivio y Educación para Menores Extranjeros permitiría a los no ciudadanos sin estatus legal que fueron traídos a Estados Unidos cuando eran niños —y que cumplan con ciertos requisitos de educación, servicio militar o trabajo— obtener estatus de residencia permanente legal. Sin embargo, la medida sigue estancada desde que se presentó por primera vez en 2001.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2022/11/16/23462526/sen-dick-durbin-time-running-out-for-senate-to-pass-dreamer-legislation" target="_blank" >Durbin ha presentado</a> la legislación en cada Congreso desde entonces, incluida la Ley DREAM de 2025 junto a la senadora Lisa Murkowski, republicana por Alaska.</p><p>Lee, nacida en Sao Paulo, Brasil, llegó a Estados Unidos con sus padres a los 2 años legalmente con visas de visitante y creció en Chicago. Tenía 12 años cuando se enteró de su estatus migratorio y descubrió que su padre tenía miedo de llenar cualquier documento que pudiera atraer la atención a su estatus migratorio. Un maestro de música de la Secundaria Lane Tech la ayudó a ser aceptada en la Merit School of Music, y la escuela finalmente la ayudó a finalizar sus estudios universitarios.</p><p>Lee obtuvo un doctorado en la Manhattan School of Music y ha enseñado allí desde 2011. Hizo su debut en Carnegie Hall en 2009; ahora es ciudadana estadounidense.</p><p>El representante Jesús “Chuy” García anunció el mes pasado que <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/04/marimar-martinez-baleada-por-agentes-de-migracion-se-pronuncia-contra-asesinatos" target="_blank" >Marimar Martínez</a>, la mujer de Chicago a la que agentes de la Patrulla Fronteriza le dispararon cinco veces el otoño pasado, sería su invitada.</p><p>La invitada del representante Raja Krishnamoorthi es una estudiante de 21 años de la Universidad de Illinois en Chicago cuyo padre fue detenido en Broadview durante el pico del Operativo Midway Blitz, y la representante Robin Kelly llevará a la directora ejecutiva de la Urban League de Chicago, Karen Freeman-Wilson. La invitada del representante Bill Foster es Suzanne Hoban, fundadora y directora ejecutiva de la Clínica de Salud Familiar, que proporciona atención médica a adultos no asegurados en el Condado de McHenry.</p><p>La representante Nikki Budzinski lleva a Laura Petty, una constituyente de Alton, Illinois, cuya familia ha sido afectada por el aumento de los costos de atención médica, y el representante Brad Schneider llevará al director ejecutivo de Learning Resources, Rick Woldenberg, quien demandó a la administración de Trump por aranceles. La semana pasada, la Corte Suprema <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/economy/2026/02/20/supreme-court-trump-sweeping-tariffs-john-roberts-economic-agenda" target="_blank" >anuló</a> los amplios aranceles de Trump, y la empresa de Woldenberg fue uno de los demandantes en esa demanda.</p><p>El invitado del representante Jonathan Jackson es el pastor Sandy Gillespie, defensor que lucha contra los recortes al Programa de Asistencia Nutricional Suplementaria (SNAP) y contra el hambre. La invitada de la representante Lauren Underwood será la pastora Jennifer Amy-Dressler de la iglesia Open Table United Church of Christ en Ottawa.</p><p>El líder demócrata de la Cámara, Hakeem Jeffries, anunció el lunes que traerá un constituyente, así como miembros de la familia del Reverendo Jesse Jackson como invitados. Su oficina no especificó qué miembros de la familia asistirán.</p><p>Jeffries dijo de Jackson, quien falleció el 17 de febrero a la edad de 84 años, “el Reverendo Jackson fue una figura política transformadora y un pionero extraordinario que luchó para que América cumpliera su promesa de ser una democracia multirracial próspera” comentó.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Tina Sfondeles

entries.title: No Shot Clock high school basketball podcast: Previewing the IHSA 4A and 3A regionals
entries.summary: <p>Joe Henricksen and Michael O’Brien’s weekly breakdown of Illinois high school basketball.</p><p>This week’s episode opens with Two Takes and then Mike and Joe break down some of the best regionals in the IHSA Class 4A and Class 3A state tournaments.</p><p><b>The podcast is on </b><a class="Link" href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/no-shot-clock/id947571011" target="_blank" ><b>Apple Podcasts</b></a><b> and </b><a class="Link" href="https://open.spotify.com/show/2pmeJqzZusnzjQy7lXfP3m?si=ILyseKvYTxqjcoYRo3tMuA" target="_blank" ><b>Spotify</b></a><b>, so please subscribe.</b></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-8a0000" name="html-embed-module-8a0000"></a><iframe title="No Shot Clock, Ep. 203: Previewing the IHSA regionals" allowtransparency="true" height="150" width="100%" style="border: none; min-width: min(100%, 430px);height:150px;" scrolling="no" data-name="pb-iframe-player" src="https://www.podbean.com/player-v2/?i=dkgi7-1a54d58-pb&from=pb6admin&share=1&download=1&rtl=0&fonts=Arial&skin=1&font-color=auto&logo_link=episode_page&btn-skin=c73a3a" loading="lazy"></iframe> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Michael O'Brien

entries.title: Man and dog shot in West Pullman
entries.summary: <p>Police are looking for an assailant in a red car who opened fire, shooting a man and his dog Tuesday morning in the West Pullman neighborhood. </p><p>It happened about 7:25 a.m. in the 300 block of East 117th Street, according to police. </p><p>The victim, a 50-year-old male was outside with his dog when a gunman exited a red car, approached on foot and opened fire, hitting the man in the abdomen and buttocks and the dog in its shoulder, police said. </p><p>The man was taken to Advocate Christ Medical Center in Oak Lawn, where he was in good condition. The dog was also in good condition, police said. </p><p>The shooter returned to the rec car and sped away. </p><p>Area 2 detectives are investigating.<br></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: 'Roller coaster' of temps in Chicago should peak above 50 this week
entries.summary: <p>The Chicago area can expect a brief warm up Friday, with temperatures forecast to reach above 50 degrees.</p><p>But leading up to Friday, temperatures will remain in the 20s and 30s, with potential flurries Wednesday night and Thursday morning, according to the National Weather Service.</p><p>“A little bit of a roller coaster up and down with temperatures,” NWS meteorologist Gino Izzi said of this week.</p><p>The chances of snow mid-week have “been going down,” he said. “It’s looking more and more likely that it’s going to miss the Chicago area to the south.”</p><p>Friday is forecast for a high of 53 degrees and sunny skies, with an overnight low of 34 degrees. Temperatures will fall back into the 40s and 30s Saturday and Sunday, according to the weather service.</p><p>Last week, Chicago experienced spring-like temperatures and a Feb. 16 <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/weather/2026/02/16/chicago-forecast-warm-weather-record-high-temperature-monday" target="_blank" >record high</a> of 65 degrees.</p>
entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: Arrest in murder of Uber driver on West Side
entries.summary: <p>Chicago police have one person in custody Tuesday after the killing of 28-year-old Daniel L. Figueroa, who was delivering food when the attack happened on the city's West Side. </p><p>No charges have been announced but a Chicago police spokesperson confirmed the arrest of a "person of interest."</p><p>Figueroa, 28, was in the 5500 block of West Flournoy Street when <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/23/death-of-downers-grove-man-found-on-austin-street-probed-as-homicide-police-say" target="_blank" >he was attacked about 2:10 a.m. Monday, police said. </a></p><p>Figueroa, of suburban Westmont, was taken to Mount Sinai Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 2:46 a.m., according to the Cook County medical examiner's office. A cause and manner of his death was not immediately known. An autopsy was scheduled. </p><p>“We’re incredibly saddened by this tragic loss, and our thoughts are with their family and loved ones as they navigate this unimaginably difficult time," an emailed statement from Uber said. "We’ve reached out to police and will assist them however we can.”<br></p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Bears, Falcons agree that Bears should receive compensatory 3rd-round draft picks for Ian Cunningham leaving
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — If <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >the Bears</a> and Falcons agree that the Bears should get compensatory draft picks for the Falcons hiring former Bears executive Ian Cunningham as their general manager last month, it should be pretty straightforward.</p><p>It’s not, of course.</p><p>While the NFL gives a team two third-round picks when another team hires one of its minority staffers as general manager, it said the Bears will not get one for <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2025/05/22/bears-joint-practices-bills-dolphins-preseason-opener-date-time-set" >Cunningham</a>, who is Black, because Falcons president of football Matt Ryan has final authority on personnel decisions.</p><p>The Bears are appealing that, general manager Ryan Poles said, and Cunningham is on their side in that dispute.</p><p>“It was always my interpretation that if a general manager gets hired, that team would receive two third-round picks,” he said Tuesday at the NFL Scouting Combine, though he acknowledged he hasn’t spent much time parsing the rule. “I’m the general manager. I was hired. I would think that they would get two third-round picks.</p><p>“That’s just my perspective. I wouldn’t be sitting here if it weren’t for them giving me that job and helping me grow to get this job.”</p><p>Cunningham worked as assistant general manager from 2022 through last season. The Falcons hired him Jan. 29, and the Bears promoted Jeff King to his former spot.</p><p>If the NFL reverses its position, the Bears would receive a compensatory third-round pick this year and next. While Poles was clear that has nothing to do with supporting Cunningham’s career advancement, he believed the Bears should get the benefit of the policy.</p><p>“I’m really proud that Ian has an opportunity to be a general manager — something we’ve talked about for a long time,” Poles said. “How we [developed and supported him] and why we do that has nothing to do with comp whatsoever, and I want to make that very clear.</p><p>“On the other side of it, there’s a set of rules that were put in place that can be applied to this situation. So we’ve communicated through the right channels, so we’ll see what happens.”</p><p>As of now, the Bears have one pick in each of the first three rounds, beginning at No. 25 overall.</p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Bears won't rule out trading backup QB Tyson Bagent
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — Ben Johnson was asked Tuesday about the possibility the Bears trade backup quarterback Tyson Bagent, a player with whom he's been enamored since taking the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a>' head coaching job a year ago.</p><p>He pulled his right hand to his mouth in dramatic fashion and let out a fake cough.</p><p>"No!" he coughed into the air.</p><p>Johnson doesn't joke often. This one got laughs. Then he got serious.</p><p>The Bears have had teams call about Bagent's availability. They haven't said no. </p><p>"I love Tyson," Johnson said. "And that’s one that kind of pulls at your heartstrings a little bit because he’s someone that you care about so deeply and he’s a hell of a football player that at some point you want to see him have a chance to do it himself. </p><p>"And so we’ll always do what’s best for our team and our organization. I do think there’s a lot of merit to having a strong No. 2 quarterback, which he certainly fits that bill. I’m of the mind that he’s probably one of the best 32 of the NFL. His preseason tape over the last couple years has probably confirmed that, in my opinion. But if I took myself out of the equation, I want what’s best for him. If he would like an opportunity to start I certainly hope he can get that somewhere."</p><p>Rather than shoot down a trade possibility Tuesday at the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/23/bears-nfl-scouting-combine-four-questions-ryan-poles-ben-johnson-salary-cap-space-tremaine-edmunds-draft-defensive-line-offensive-trade-maxx-crosby-raiders" target="_blank" >NFL Scouting Combine</a>, Bears GM Ryan Poles called any potential move an “interesting dynamic that we’re going to have to work through.”</p><p>Poles plucked Bagent out of Div. II Shepherd University and he quickly won the Bears' backup job in 2023. Poles and Johnson so value Bagent that they gave him a two-year, $10 million extension last year that runs though the end of the 2027 season. The Bears haven’t needed him the last two years, though — with Caleb Williams making every start, Bagent has thrown just six passes.</p><p>Williams’ perfect run of health won’t continue forever, though. If the Bears trade him, they’d have to find a solid backup to take his place. The Bears would probably need a Day 2 draft pick just to consider a move.</p><p>The Bears anticipated teams would call about Bagent’s availability given a weak free agent and rookie class at quarterback. He's cheap and has been effective — in his four rookie starts and all three preseasons of his career.</p><p>“The tough thing is, with what Ben thinks about Tyson, what I think about Tyson, what our locker room thinks about Tyson, that’s a really tough decision for us,” Poles said. “But for Tyson as well, I think he would have an opportunity to go and perform for a team and do some really good things.</p><p>“But again, you’ve got to weigh the short-term and the long-term. Now, what’s the cost for replacement? We spent a lot of time developing him. Ben spent a lot of time developing him.”</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Frustrated Illinois congressional candidates call super PAC influence 'buying a seat'
entries.summary: <p>Super PACs benefiting cryptocurrency, artificial intelligence and Israel are actively working to influence Illinois congressional races — and candidates in four already competitive and crowded districts aren’t happy.</p><p>They’re likening the super PAC support to buying a seat and dark money bombardment. Others are accusing Democrats of being beholden to interests that will benefit President Donald Trump’s administration — a clearly unpopular issue for Democrats in a primary.</p><p>“It seems like easy pickings for the types of giant corporate interest that wants to come in and spend,” said Reed Showalter, a candidate in the<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-about-illinois-7th-congressional-district-democratic-primary" target="_blank" > 7th Congressional District</a>. “A few million dollars to buy a seat in Congress is a good deal. And for the rest of everybody who’s playing a grassroots game, that is a very damaging thing.”</p><p>Showalter is one of several candidates speaking out about the influence of super PACs in this primary cycle — in an unprecedented year with four open congressional seats and a Senate seat open in Illinois. </p><p>The American Israel Public Affairs Committee — the powerful pro-Israel organization — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/19/rep-jan-schakowsky-withdrawal-donna-miller-endorsement-2nd-congressional-district-aipac-support" >is playing a role</a> in four congressional races in Illinois — helping to boost Cook County Commissioner Donna Miller in the 2nd; former U.S. Rep. Melissa Bean in the 8th; state Sen. Laura Fine in the 9th; and Chicago City Treasurer Melissa Conyears Ervin in the 7th. United Democracy Project, AIPAC’s affiliated super PAC, has spent more than $753,000 directly to support Conyears Ervin.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-2nd-congressional-district-democratic-primary" target="_blank" >The 2nd District</a> is especially hit hard by super PAC influence, with Fairshake, a pro-crypto PAC funded primarily by Trump megadonors and business partners Marc Andreessen and Ben Horowitz, targeting state Sen. Robert Peters. Fairshake is spending at least $1 million to run anti-Peters ads. And it’s the third Trump-affiliated super PAC to play a role in the race.</p><p>Andreessen is the founder and general partner of Silicon Valley venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz — and a Trump adviser on tech and business policy — and he gave more than $4.7 million to advance the MAGA agenda in the 2023 and 2024 electoral cycle.</p><p>Affordable Chicago Now!, which is AIPAC-affiliated, is spending money in support of Miller, while the Leading the Future PAC, funded by OpenAI stakeholders, is backing former Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr. in the race.</p><p>Peters’ campaign says Fairshake is targeting him because he voted for crypto state legislation that imposed new rules on digital asset firms. Peters co-sponsored the measure.</p><p>“I think any time big right wing billionaire donors come into a race, it’s like a jolt,” Peters said.</p><p>Peters said all three entities “are scared of having an effective progressive champion in this seat.”</p><p>“There’s a whole group of really corrupt billionaires who have really close attachment to the Trump administration, who want people who are going to be soft on their issues, and so that means people who are going to be OK with unconditional military aid in [Israel Prime Minister Benjamin] Netanyahu’s war machine," Peters said. "That means people who are going to be OK with the advancement of AI slop and the increase in utility rates. That means people who are OK with the corrupt practices of the crypto bros who have been literally benefiting from the Trump administration, and I believe have played a role in Trump’s ability to gain more wealth.”</p><p>Junaid Ahmed, a candidate in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/02/06/what-to-know-about-illinois-8th-congressional-district-democratic-primary" target="_blank" >8th Congressional District,</a> is a progressive endorsed by the Sunrise Movement, who is also railing against the influence of super PACs. He’s frustrated that mailers call Bean an “architect of Obamacare,” and reference a 2010 Chicago Tribune article about her role in Obamacare — though in reality the article discusses how she had not made a decision to sign the measure. Bean ultimately did support Obamacare. </p><p>“That’s the part that dark money is doing here. When a voter sees that kind of bombardment, the shouting from the rooftops, that’s a direct impact,” Ahmed said. “And they’re able to by making ads on any topic that polls well — don’t even bring the word AI, don’t even bring the word AIPAC — just focus on what’s polling well and then bombard the voters, and then buy our races.”</p><p>Showalter, a former attorney for the Federal Trade Commission and U.S. Justice Department counsel, said publicly funding elections — and ending Citizens United — would make a huge difference in deflating the power of special interests. He credited New York City's program, in which candidates receive public funding that partially matches what they raise, for helping Zohran Mamdani win the mayoral seat. </p><p>"You have a matching program where you raise up to a million dollars and it's matched 8-to-1," Showalter said. "That makes a big difference for people who are candidates who are running in a grassroots publicly supported way, so that you don't have to rely on the millions and millions of dollars that can, frankly, only be deployed by giant corporate interests."</p>
entries.author: Tina Sfondeles

entries.title: Singer-songwriter BJRNCK prepares for homecoming show: ‘What would Beyonce do if she performed at Schubas?’
entries.summary: <p>There’s a new generation of songstresses emerging from the rich R&B tradition built by Black Chicagoans like Minnie Riperton and Chaka Khan. Singer-songwriter <a class="Link" href="https://www.bjrnck.com/" target="_blank" ><u>BJRNCK</u></a> is a part of this new era, embarking on her first headlining tour back home to Chicago at Schubas on Feb. 25, bringing to life her debut album, “A Girl Like Me.”</p><p>The show will be a dramatic, immersive experience that brings fans into her decade-long journey. BJRNCK (pronounced byo͝or’nik), born Gennae Bewernick, aims to illustrate a relatable story of navigating womanhood and her journey as a singer. The hourlong performance will be narrated through music and skits that draw inspiration from her favorite film, the 1996 comedy-thriller “A Thin Line Between Love and Hate,” and the album itself.</p><p>“I broke it down into sections. My album is like ‘Girl, I’ve been there too,’ but we’re learning. It’s like therapy albums. I want the show to feel like that. What would Beyonce do if she performed at Schubas?” she said.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-250000" name="module-250000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>BJRNCK: AGLM (A Girl Like Me) Tour</h3><br><b>When:</b> Feb. 25<br><b>Where</b>: Schubas Tavern, 3159 N. Southport Ave.<br><b>Tickets</b>: $20<br><b>Info:</b> <a class="Link" href="https://lh-st.com/shows/02-25-2026-bjrnck/" target="_blank" ><u>https://lh-st.com/shows/02-25-2026-bjrnck/</u></a></div> </div><p>The sultry offering, “A Girl Like Me,” released in October, was years in the making. A part of the local music scene since she was 16, she spent two years recording the album after signing with Geffen/Interscope Records. After years of releasing singles and collaborating with stars like Saba, HappyBirthdayCalvin, Chloe, Omarion and Babyface (who was nominated for a Grammy in 2024 for “Girls Night Out,” which featured an extended version bonus track with BJRNCK), she approached her breakout debut as a way to introduce herself.</p><p>“I’m still a new artist to the world. How can I fit all the pieces of me that people have missed into this album, like who I am and what I’ve been through?” she said.</p><p>The struggle of the beginning of her career is encapsulated in the album’s title track. The song samples an old video she recorded of herself documenting the grueling realities of being a singer on the come-up. Her mother sent her that video, and it inspired her to use it as the album’s intro.</p><p>“I was in my basement in Chicago, sitting on my bed, I looked so sad. And I’m like, ‘it’s OK because one day, I’m going to be rich as f---, and I’m going to make a lot of money,” she said.</p><p>Born in Los Angeles, where she is based now, BJRNCK and her family moved to the South Side when she was a 6-year-old girl. She grew up in the Altgeld Gardens housing projects and later moved to 81st Street and King Drive in Chatham. She attended Roseland Middle School with fellow singer Ravyn Lenae and rapper Adamn Killa, long before he was rapping, in fifth grade. She and Lenae would share a kinship, claiming each other as sisters.</p><p>She recalls Lenae sharing videos of her singing and being reluctant to upload them on YouTube. BJRNCK would encourage Lenae to post them anyway, believing in her singing talent. </p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/music/2025/07/30/ravyn-lenae-chicago-high-school-arts-lollapalooza-sabrina-carpenter" >Rising star Ravyn Lenae dropped by her former Chicago high school to offer this inspiring message</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>“I’m so proud of her. And it’s just inspiring because it’s like, I know my time is coming. We were all in the same area, we’re cut from the same cloth. Everybody gets their time. … Adamn wasn’t even doing music when we were in middle school, so even going viral and doing what he’s doing now is so fire,” she said of the rapper who went viral late last year for his <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/11/10/chicago-rapper-adamn-killa-tells-cops-to-arrest-me-daddy-getting-arrested-wont-stop-him" target="_blank" >“arrest me, daddy” videos</a>.</p><p>In the spirit of her predecessors, Tink, Dreezy, and icons like Jennifer Hudson and Shawnna, BJRNCK’s music epitomizes the fiery, bold, yet misunderstood spirit of authentic Black Chicago women — loving, honest, yet shaped into warriors by the harsh, patriarchal environments around them. For her, it's about showcasing that duality between softness and assertiveness, especially to the younger generation of girls who listen to her music.</p><p>“I think that it’s important for me, coming from the city and young girls listening to my music, to show, yeah, I’m aggressive, but there’s that sweet side too. It’s OK to be a girl and OK to be soft,” she said.</p><p>For BJRNCK, her homecoming show and the album are a victory lap after being behind the scenes. And with her forthcoming deluxe edition of “A Girl Like Me” arriving this summer, she is working harder than ever to blaze her own trail to superstardom.</p><p>“Some people think that I just got everything, I got all the resources, and it’s like, no, I’ve been grinding for 10 years trying to make it to this moment. But I wouldn’t have had it any other way,” she said.</p>
entries.author: Mark Braboy | For the Sun-Times

entries.title: UIC student to attend State of the Union after father's deportation left him raising his younger sisters
entries.summary: <p>Less than a year after college student Jaime Coria Jr. lost his mother to a rare form of cancer, his father was detained by federal agents during the peak of "Operation Midway Blitz" and sent over 2,000 miles away to Mexico City.</p><p>In the months since, Coria Jr. has balanced his studies pursuing a psychology degree at the University of Illinois Chicago with raising his two younger sisters as they live off of survivor's benefits they received after their mother's passing. </p><p>"It's very hard talking about this emotionally because we lost our mother in the beginning of 2025 and then we lose our father eight to nine months later," Coria Jr., 21, told the Sun-Times from Washington, D.C., Tuesday morning. </p><p>Coria Jr. is in Washington to attend the State of the Union address Tuesday night as a guest of U.S. Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi. The two connected after Coria Jr.'s father was detained in early October near their Mount Prospect apartment complex in Krishnamoorthi's district. </p><p>"It's a story of a family that was going through tremendous hardship," Krishnamoorthi said. "Donald Trump says he was going after the worst of the worst when he came into office, and I think Jaime's family represents really what has ended up being the target of Donald Trump's efforts — loving families who are trying to survive ... and now he's torn them apart." </p><p>Coria Jr.'s father spent four days in "inhumane" conditions at the Immigration and Customs Enforcement processing center in west suburban Broadview before self-deporting to Mexico where he is currently working full-time and living in his childhood home. </p><p>He was packed into a windowless room with about 60 men, denied showers, forced to sleep on the floor or standing up and witnessed multiple detainees hauled away on stretchers, according to Krishnamoorthi. He signed a voluntary departure form and was deported the next day though his attorney secured an emergency hearing that could have halted his removal. </p><p>"He decided to pretty much sign his rights away," Coria Jr. said. "He wasn't made aware of his legal options at that point." </p><p>Krishnamoorthi inspected the Broadview facility in December after previous attempts were denied and said the building was "not designed in any way to house people." </p><p>"What it shows is that if there's not oversight, bad things happen. And bad things were happening in Broadview ... so that's all the more reason for people like me to do oversight duties," Krishnamoorthi said. "I'm going to stand up to them eight days a week because of what happened." </p><p>Krishnamoorthi emphasized that Coria Jr.'s story highlights a broader pattern of detainees being "put in inhumane conditions, coerced into signing away their rights and denied due process." </p><p>Less than a month after Coria Jr.'s father self-deported, a court <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/12/federal-judge-orders-release-hundreds-feds-deportation-midway-blitz-warrantless-arrests" target="_blank" >ordered 615 detainees</a> released in an attempt to "restore the status quo that existed before the Trump administration recently changed its interpretation of immigration law."</p><p>Coria Jr.'s father was recently denied an immigration visa during an appointment at the Consulate of Mexico, and the family's attorney is currently working on a response to that denial, Coria Jr. said. </p><p>He also noted his father "breaks the Trump administration’s agenda" about immigrants. He paid taxes every year for roughly two decades, never owed money to the IRS, never voted in an election and never has taken government benefits. </p><p>Coria Jr.'s father has been a roofer for three decades and played a pivotal role in helping take care of his wife of 10 years as she battled cholangiocarcinoma, a rare kind of liver cancer. </p><p>The college junior's father took her to the emergency room on multiple occasions and waited until she was stabilized before working his labor-intensive job and returning to the hospital, staying overnight to make sure she was OK. </p><p>"My mom's oncologist even wrote a letter talking about my dad's moral character," Coria Jr. said. "He never got angry with me or my siblings [and] he always gave us advice." </p><p>Coria Jr. urges others who had loved ones detained under harsh conditions at Broadview to speak out. </p><p>"The way we treat people is not something that should be up for debate," Coria Jr. said. "We as a country should expect better for the treatment of immigrants in general." <br></p>
entries.author: Mohammad Samra

entries.title: No matter where Bears end up, Chicago stakes claim for $630 million for Soldier Field overhaul
entries.summary: <p>Chicago is no longer part of the conversation to build the domed stadium needed to keep the Bears in Illinois and stave off a move to Indiana. <br>But the Chicago Park District wants a piece of the action — if the team scores the state help it needs to build a dome in Arlington Heights.</p><p>With or without the Bears, the Chicago Park District wants $630 million to renovate and refresh Soldier Field, and ease the transportation bottleneck that makes it difficult to get in and out of the Museum Campus.</p><p>Roughly $500 million would be spent on long-sought infrastructure improvements. The remaining $130 million would be used for replacement of stadium seats, an upgrade of Soldier Field’s concessions, restrooms, locker rooms, video and sound systems, and an overhaul of luxury skyboxes and club level lounges.</p><p>The new revamp would also include structural, mechanical, electrical, plumbing and exterior improvements, even as Chicago taxpayers remain saddled with $467 million in outstanding debt linked to the 2001 renovation of Soldier Field. </p><p>The wish list of improvements was devised by Legends Global, a company that manages nearly a dozen NFL stadiums and is now leading the development of Alicante Park, a new sports and entertainment complex being built outside the Valencia, Spain.</p><p>The overhaul would include fencing and façade work, as well as unspecified improvements to the parking lots surrounding Soldier Field.</p><p>The transportation improvements are the same as those floated by Mayor Brandon Johnson when he teamed up with Bears President Kevin Warren on a plan to build a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2024/04/23/bears-new-stadium-dome-lakefront-soldier-field" >domed lakefront stadium</a> on a parking lot adjacent to Soldier Field.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-340000" name="image-340000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/57c0c26/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3840x2155+0+2/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F36%2F2e%2F99cd06a24ca3a620ff0cb49ba0d3%2Fbearsstadium-042424-06.jpg data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A rendering of a new stadium that was once proposed for the Bears on the lakefront.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided/Chicago Bears</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>That plan went nowhere in Springfield, prompting the Bears to shift their focus back to the Arlington International Racecourse site that the team purchased for $197.2 million and has already cleared for development.</p><p> The Bears are trying to work out an agreement with the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2025/06/01/bears-stadium-bill-springfield" >Illinois General Assembly </a>on a so-called “mega-projects” bill that would save the team hundreds of millions of dollars by freezing property taxes and allowing the team to negotiate reduced “payments in lieu of property taxes” with suburban school districts.</p><p>The deal would also include up to $700 million in road, sewer and utility work needed to pave the way for construction of a domed stadium on the Arlington Heights site.</p><p>The Park District’s 11th hour play for a piece of stadium funding throws a potential monkey wrench into Bears stadium negotiations.</p><p>The Bears stadium bill can’t pass without substantial support from the General Assembly's Chicago lawmakers. If Chicago legislators demand a Soldier Field refresh in exchange for their votes, the heat would be on to find the money to appease Chicago.</p><h3>‘We want them to stay’</h3><p>Chicago Park District Superintendent Carlos Ramirez-Rosa said the $500 million needed to ease the notorious transportation bottleneck around Soldier Field could come from the “motor fuel tax lock box money,” the state’s road fund that has $3.5 billion that “needs to be spent down.”</p><p>The $130 million for a Soldier Field revamp could come, in part, from the penalty the Bears would pay if they terminate their lease, or if the Park District pursues the more aggressive legal theory that the Bears owe a 150% of the annual rent penalty from the moment they started looking for a new stadium.</p><p>“We believe the Bears belong here. We want them to stay in Chicago, but if that ship is sailed or sailing, then we’re prepared to plan for the future of Soldier Field to maintain it as a viable asset for large concerts, for large international and national sporting events that drives the local tourism economy, that puts heads in beds downtown and generates revenue for the city of Chicago, for the Park District,” Ramirez-Rosa said.</p><p></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-e10000" name="image-e10000"></a> <picture 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/36db76a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1920x1078+0+1/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F7f%2Ffd%2Fa163ff2544cca35ed98baf736df3%2Fbears-stadium-rendering-01.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Renderings of the proposed Chicago Bears stadium in Arlington Heights.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided by Manica Architecture</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Ramirez-Rosa stressed that Soldier Field is “in great shape,” and remains the “largest non-tax revenue source” for the Chicago Park District — with $62.9 million in projected gross revenue that reduces pressure to raise property taxes and supports Park District programs citywide.</p><p>Last year alone, Soldier Field played host to thirteen concert nights, including five straight over Labor Day weekend. Beyonce concerts in May 2025 generated $85 million in hotel revenue and 98.5% occupancy in downtown hotels.</p><p>Those numbers are all the more reason to “continue to invest” in Chicago’s lakefront stadium, in part by making it “easier to get in and out” of Soldier Field, Ramirez-Rosa said.</p><p>“The plan that the Bears unveiled with the mayor would have fixed a lot of those issues," Ramirez-Rosa said. "It was a great plan that would have benefited the South Loop. It would have benefited the museum campus. It would have made it easier for people to get in and out of the museum campus and Soldier Field. Those issues don’t go away if the Bears go to Arlington Heights or Indiana.” </p><p>Senior mayoral adviser Jason Lee said the Johnson administration’s “number one focus is trying to make sure that Chicago remains in the mix to keep the Bears.”</p><p>“The partnership between the Park District and the Bears has been good for a number of reasons. We’d like to maintain it through some mechanism, and that’s what they’re having conversations in Springfield about,” Lee said. “This [Soldier Field Hail Mary] is just about saying, `We’re not going to lay down and die if it goes the other way.’ But our focus is preserving what we have.”</p><h3>Springfield waits for details</h3><p>Sources close to the Bears’ Springfield negotiations said talks were heading in a positive direction despite the frustration caused by the team’s <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/19/chicago-bears-stadium-hammond-indiana-move" >Hammond announcement </a>last week. A committee hearing was set for Thursday on the bill the Bears are seeking that would allow them negotiate payments in lieu of taxes (PILOT) to local taxing bodies, resulting in lower property tax liabilities.</p><p>But getting close to a deal behind closed doors is a long way away from locking up 60 votes in the Illinois House and 30 in the Senate, where Chicago Democrats across the Capitol remain loath to pave the Bears’ way out of town.</p><p>Some city legislators are still holding out hope the Bears will reconsider the old Michael Reese Hospital site that the team has dismissed as too narrow, but most acknowledge it’s down to Arlington Heights or Indiana. One legislator noted that Johnson has been “a complete nonentity” in stadium negotiations since the mayor’s ill-fated boosterism of the Bears proposal for a lakefront stadium. </p><p></p><p>Gov. JB Pritzker’s office wasn’t briefed on the park district funding plan. While he was optimistic about talks, Pritzker acknowledged “I really don't know whether they will choose to move out of the state.”</p><p>“We continue to have really positive discussions with the Chicago Bears, and I think you're going to see progress over time here," Pritzker said Tuesday. "I'm a Chicago Bears fan, believe very much that they ought to be based in Illinois, and I'm going to do everything I can without harming the taxpayers of the state of Illinois in the process of making sure that we can do everything we can to keep them in the state.”</p><p>State Sen. Bill Cunningham, a South Side Democrat and a key negotiator in Bears talks, said he had not heard from park district officials about the funding proposal and was “unaware of anyone who has.” Spokespeople for House Speaker Emanuel “Chris” Welch and Senate President Don Harmon said they also hadn’t reviewed the ideas.</p><p>State Sen. Robert Peters, whose district includes Soldier Field, said that without being briefed on the potential upgrades, he’d be on board with doing “whatever we need to do to make sure it remains one of the best concert venues in the country.”</p><p>“It’s a top-tier stadium for the likes of Beyonce and Taylor Swift. If you can fill it for eight to 10 more concerts, that’ll easily make up for the potential loss of Bears revenue,” Peters said. “There’s a fallacy that sports stadiums are this huge economic driver. The Bears are not that great of a driver of revenue for Soldier Field. They make a massive blackout period and take all the revenue from it.”</p><p>While Peters isn’t completely resigned to the Bears leaving the city, “we do have to have a conversation about what happens when the Bears convince someone to give them a handout,” he said.</p><p>“Indiana is willing to tax working-class people to pay for billionaires’ new stadium, and the [Arlington Heights] PILOT bill seems like it’s moving, so we're now at a point where we have to think realistically about options on what is next,” Peters said. “Infrastructure support is understandable, but I personally am never going to support tax giveaways to build a new stadium.”</p><p>Hoosier lawmakers are poised to pass legislation this week creating a new stadium finance authority and a slew of new taxes to pump upwards of $1 billion into a new stadium, along with $2 billion from the Bears.</p><p>Under the legislation that passed the Indiana House on Tuesday, the Bears would be able to buy it for a buck once 40-year bonds are paid off, backed by taxes on admissions, hotel stays, and food and beverage costs within a stadium district. In the meantime, the Bears would sign a 35-year lease that would allow the team to retain all revenues generated by the stadium.</p><p></p><p></p>
entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: Ald. Shirley Drewenski elected acting Harvey mayor
entries.summary: <p>The Harvey City Council elected an acting mayor one month after the death of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/01/30/harvey-mayor-christopher-j-clark-dead" target="_blank" >Mayor Christopher Clark</a>.</p><p>Ald. Shirley Drewenski (1st) was unanimously selected during Monday’s City Council meeting and was sworn in to serve the remainder of Clark’s term through next year.</p><p>Drewenski had previously been sworn in as mayor pro tempore after Clark’s death. Her appointment comes after two prior council votes ended in ties. A majority vote is required for the appointment.</p><p>Drewenski did not immediately respond to a request for comment.</p><p>Clark died Jan. 30 and served as mayor for six years. The cause of his death has not been revealed.</p><p>A memorial service will be held for Clark on March 28, according to the city.<br></p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: Exrepresentante de Illinois relata momentos aterradores a punta de pistola con cártel en Puerto Vallarta
entries.summary: <p>Temprano el domingo por la mañana, Jonathan “Yoni” Pizer viajaba rumbo a una excursión de avistamiento de ballenas en Puerto Vallarta, México, disfrutando de sus vacaciones de invierno en Chicago en un lugar que ha visitado por décadas.</p><p>Pizer, su esposo y dos amigos estaban conduciendo cuando un vehículo frente a ellos hizo un giro en U abrupto, dijo. Vieron una camioneta estacionada en la intersección y a un hombre con un arma corriendo hacia ellos.</p><p>El hombre apuntó su arma a través de la ventana del auto y les gritó en español. Pizer y su grupo se bajaron del vehículo, mientras el hombre apuntaba su arma en la cara de Pizer. Luego, el hombre se subió al asiento del conductor, maniobró el auto para bloquear la calle y lo estacionó. Segundos después, el vehículo empezó a arder en llamas.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-0d0000" name="module-0d0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“Antes de que nos diéramos cuenta, nuestro auto alquilado y la camioneta estaban en llamas”, contó Pizer.</p><p>Pizer, exrepresentante estatal de Illinois que ahora trabaja para el representante Mike Quigley, observó cómo el hombre se subía a un autobús de la ciudad y disparaba al aire, ordenando a la gente que se bajara del bus. Pronto, el autobús también se incendió.</p><p>En medio de la conmoción, Pizer envió mensajes de texto frenéticos a amigos en su condominio cercano.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-971a8b" name="image-971a8b"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490"
