2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/725c919/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F30%2F18%2Fe2b40b1fb232f3e1c484370d3448%2F12th-il-house-jonathan-22yoni-22-pizer.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Jonathan “Yoni” Pizer iba rumbo a observar ballenas en Puerto Vallarta, México, el domingo, cuando un miembro armado de un cártel detuvo su auto a punta de pistola y lo incendió.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Proporcionada</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“¡¡¡MUCHACHOS, NO SALGAN DE LA CASA!!!! ¡¡¡NO ES UNA BROMA!!!”, escribió.</p><p>“¡Ataque terrorista!” envió en mensaje minutos después.</p><p>“¡¡¡Quédense en la casa, avisen a seguridad!!!”, texteó.</p><p>Lo que Pizer y su grupo no sabían era que el Ejército Mexicano había matado al líder del <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/23/muere-el-mencho-lider-del-cartel-jalisco-nueva-generacion" target="_blank" >Cártel Jalisco Nueva Generación (CJNG), Nemesio Rubén Oseguera Cervantes</a>, conocido como “El Mencho”. Las carreteras estuvieron bloqueadas durante horas con vehículos en llamas, una táctica utilizada por los cárteles para impedir operativos militares.</p><p>Pizer y su grupo quedaron atrapados en las primeras horas de caos en las calles de Puerto Vallarta. Él y un amigo se separaron de sus esposos. Un extraño les dijo que se subieran a su auto y los llevó a la playa, que permanecía apacible.</p><p>“La gente [estaba] haciendo yoga, corriendo y montando bicicletas”, comentó Pizer. “Nadie sabía lo que acababa de comenzar, e hice lo mejor que pude para decirles a las personas que había un ataque terrorista en marcha”.</p><p>Pizer y su amigo caminaron por la playa de regreso a su condominio; sus esposos se refugiaron en un orfanato en una iglesia cercana. Permanecieron allí durante ocho horas hasta que la violencia disminuyó y pudieron regresar al condominio.</p><p>Inestabilidad en Jalisco</p><p>Videos que circulaban en las redes sociales mostraron humo sobre la ciudad turística de Puerto Vallarta en Jalisco y a personas corriendo en pánico por el aeropuerto de la capital del estado.</p><p>Varias aerolíneas estadounidenses, canadienses, mexicanas e internacionales cancelaron vuelos.</p><p>En Guadalajara, que está programada para albergar partidos durante la Copa del Mundo de fútbol de este verano, vehículos en llamas bloquearon rutas y negocios cerraron.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-aa1ff1" name="image-aa1ff1"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/663ef61/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F94%2Fbeecad184486aa77d72f09f240af%2F2262734563.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2a745f8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F94%2Fbeecad184486aa77d72f09f240af%2F2262734563.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/669a9fa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F94%2Fbeecad184486aa77d72f09f240af%2F2262734563.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Burned cars are seen in the parking lot of a Costco retail store in Puerto Vallarta, Jalisco state, Mexico, on February 23, 2026. Mexico has deployed 10,000 troops to quell clashes sparked by the killing of the country's most wanted drug lord, which have left dozens dead, officials said on February 23. Nemesio "El Mencho" Oseguera, leader of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel (CJNG), was wounded on February 22 in a shootout with soldiers in the town of Tapalpa in Jalisco state and died while being flown to Mexico City, the army said. (Photo by Alfredo ESTRELLA / AFP via Getty Images)" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/669a9fa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F94%2Fbeecad184486aa77d72f09f240af%2F2262734563.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6f3dd69/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F94%2Fbeecad184486aa77d72f09f240af%2F2262734563.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/669a9fa/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8256x4633+0+435/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fff%2F94%2Fbeecad184486aa77d72f09f240af%2F2262734563.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Autos quemados en un estacionamiento de Costco en Puerto Vallarta, estado de Jalisco, México, el lunes. México ha desplegado 10,000 tropas para sofocar los enfrentamientos provocados por la muerte del narcotraficante más buscado del país.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>ALFREDO ESTRELLA/Getty</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>El Departamento de Estado de Estados Unidos advirtió a sus ciudadanos en los estados de Jalisco, Tamaulipas, Michoacán, Guerrero y Nuevo León que busquen refugio. El gobernador de Jalisco, Pablo Lemus, indicó a los residentes que se quedaran en casa, suspendió el transporte público y dijo que el estado estaba “viviendo horas críticas”.</p><p>Rumores circularon en las redes sociales de que la violencia podría continuar y que los servicios públicos podrían ser interrumpidos. Pero mientras Pizer y su grupo esperaban ansiosos, se hizo la calma.</p><p>“Lo que temíamos, los sucesos de terror que preocupaban durante la noche, ninguno de eso sucedió”, comentó Pizer.</p><p>Pizer dedujo que el objetivo de la violencia era comunicarle al gobierno que el cártel podría tomar un cierto nivel de control.</p><p>“Creemos que realmente se trataba de enviar un mensaje al gobierno de que podían encender y apagar la violencia a su antojo”, contó Pizer.</p><p>Agregó, “Si hubieran querido matar personas, nosotros estaríamos entre los primeros”.</p><p>Pizer expresó su preocupación sobre lo que las noticias harán por la reputación de la zona, ya que gran parte de Puerto Vallarta depende del turismo.</p><p>“Realmente queremos que las cosas vuelvan a ser el maravilloso lugar que tantas personas saben que es”, comentó Pizer. “Realmente merece nuestro apoyo y, francamente, de aquí en adelante, nuestra lealtad”.</p><p>Planes de boda interrumpidos</p><p>En preparación para su boda en Guadalajara el viernes, Kaitlin Bucaro y Robbie Morris estaban sentados en una cafetería de Chicago escribiendo sus votos matrimoniales la mañana del domingo cuando recibieron noticias de una invitada que había viajado a México y que su vuelo había sido desviado y no podía aterrizar.</p><p>La pareja leyó y vio las noticias provenientes de Guadalajara y en pocas horas supieron que tendrían que cancelar la boda de 150 invitados en la que habían pasado un año —y miles de dólares— planeando. Tenían previsto volar a México el martes por la mañana.</p><p>“Esta situación que está pasando no está necesariamente en estos contratos con estos proveedores”, dijo Bucaro.</p><p>“Creo que rápidamente nos dimos cuenta de que lo que estaba ocurriendo allí era más grande que esta boda y traer a un montón de gente”, comentó. “Necesitábamos cuidar la seguridad de todos, incluida nuestra propia seguridad.”</p><p>La pareja está “destrozada”, añadió Morris.</p><p>Han hecho amigos en Guadalajara durante varios viajes allí en los últimos años. La mañana del lunes, se comunicaron con su amigo Chuy, que vive allí después de 30 años en Chicago.</p><p>“Nos rompe el corazón ver a todos pasar por esta situación caótica y violenta”, dijo Morris. “Y estamos pensando en todos allá”.</p><p>Bucaro y Morris están tratando de encontrar un nuevo lugar en el área de Chicago para seguir adelante con su boda este viernes.</p><p><i>Con información de Associated Press </i></p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" >La Voz Chicago</a></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Trump treating U.S. women's hockey team as afterthought is no laughing matter
entries.summary: <p>Within hours of defeating Canada, the U.S. men’s hockey team received a congratulatory call from President Donald Trump and an invitation to the White House. What should have been a routine celebration of athletic excellence instead became a revealing cultural moment.</p><p>After extending the invitation, the <a class="Link" href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2026/feb/23/trump-usa-hockey-call-state-of-union" target="_blank" >president joked</a>, “I must tell you, we’re going to have to bring the women’s team,” adding that he would “probably be impeached” if they were not invited. Laughter followed.</p><p>Both the U.S. men’s and women’s teams had delivered extraordinary victories against a fierce rival. Both performances electrified fans and showcased the highest level of international competition. Yet the reactions surrounding those wins exposed something familiar: Women’s achievements are still too often treated as secondary, inconvenient or worthy of acknowledgment only as an obligation.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-b80000" name="module-b80000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Commentary bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Commentary</h2></div> </div><p>Of course, there are those defending the remark as harmless: just a joke, just locker room talk, boys will be boys. Throughout my career, I have heard similar dismissals: It’s just a toy, just a book, just a show. But words matter. And over time, they accumulate, shaping expectations about who belongs and whose accomplishments are taken seriously.</p><p>When authority figures frame inclusion as optional or burdensome, the message travels quickly. Laughter signals what feels acceptable. Silence signals what feels risky to question.</p><p>Team environments depend on unity and belonging. Speaking up can feel like breaking ranks, while remaining quiet feels safer. Yet silence, even when unintended, communicates acceptance. Over time, these moments reinforce who is perceived as central and who remains an addition.</p><p>The contrast is especially striking given the broader reality of these Olympics. Of the United States’ 12 gold medals, eight were won by women. Of the <a class="Link" href="https://slate.com/culture/2026/02/american-women-dominated-the-2026-olympics.html" target="_blank" >33 total U.S. medals</a>, women earned 21. Their performances are not supplementary to American achievement; they are foundational to it.</p><p>Disparities in recognition do more than diminish women’s accomplishments. They alter the meaning of celebration itself. The men earned their victory unequivocally, yet the surrounding controversy risks attaching an unnecessary shadow to what should have been uncomplicated national pride.</p><p>The U.S. women’s hockey team ultimately declined the White House invitation, a decision reflecting principle as much as disappointment. Recognition offered alongside dismissal rarely feels like recognition at all.</p><h3>Will men’s team stand up for women? </h3><h3></h3><p>What happens next matters.</p><p>The most meaningful response from the men’s team would require solidarity: a public acknowledgment that women athletes deserve equal respect, that jokes minimizing their inclusion are harmful and that teammates across gender lines stand together. Such a response would not diminish their victory; it would elevate it.</p><p>Such actions do not come without risk. Speaking publicly in opposition, especially to a sitting president, invites swift backlash. Athletes who step into controversy often face immediate and personal criticism. The pressure to remain silent is real.</p><p>Yet moments like this offer athletes a rare opportunity to shape something larger than a championship legacy.</p><p>If members of the men’s team were to address what happened, offering clarification and support for the women’s team, it would mark a defining act of leadership. Greatness in sports is not measured only by performance under pressure, but by courage when silence feels easier.</p><p>And people are watching.</p><p>Not only young girls, but young boys and children everywhere are learning what respect looks like in real time. They are learning whether success excuses dismissal or whether excellence includes standing up for others. They are learning how men treat women when recognition and power are on the line.</p><p>Years from now, few will remember the precise wording of a joke. But they will remember athletes choosing respect over comfort and unity over silence. They will remember players who understood that how victories are carried matters as much as how they are won.</p><p>Sports has never existed apart from culture. From Title IX to ongoing fights for equal pay and investment, athletics has long helped shape national conversations about fairness and belonging. Moments like this become lessons far beyond the rink.</p><p>When women win and are treated as an afterthought, the message reaches classrooms, workplaces and communities alike: You may help carry the nation, but you will not be centered in its story.</p><p>Inclusion without respect is not equality.</p><p>The victories over Canada should have been remembered solely for athletic brilliance: four teams competing, two American triumphs, one shared sense of pride. Instead, they revealed how persistent the work of equality remains.</p><p>The men’s team now faces an opportunity few champions receive: to ensure their victory stands not only for competitive excellence, but for integrity. A moment of solidarity could transform controversy into progress and ensure this championship is remembered not only for winning, but for leadership.</p><p>The question raised here extends beyond hockey. When women win for America, will America stand fully with them, or will equality remain an invitation extended only as an afterthought?</p><p>The answer, this time, may belong to the champions themselves.</p><p><i>Jodi Bondi Norgaard is an entrepreneur, author and gender-equity advocate. She is the creator of the award-winning Go! Go! Sports Girls brand and the author of "More Than a Doll: How Creating a Sports Doll Turned into a Fight to End Gender Stereotypes."</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d60000" name="module-d60000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Jodi Bondi Norgaard

entries.title: ‘Abolish ICE’ entre los ganadores de concurso para nombrar camiones quitanieves de Chicago
entries.summary: <p>Uno de los quitanieves de Chicago está listo para apuntar directamente al Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE). Tras miles de votos, “Abolish ICE” (“Abolir ICE”) fue nombrado como uno de los ganadores en el concurso “Nombra un quitanieve” de la Municipalidad.</p><p>El lunes, el Departamento de Calles y Saneamiento anunció los seis nombres ganadores del cuarto concurso anual de nombres para quitanieves. Estos fueron seleccionados entre más de 13,300 propuestas y 39,000 votantes.</p><p>Los seis nombres de quitanieves que recibieron más votos también incluyeron “Stephen Coldbert”, “Pope Frío XIV”, “The Blizzard of Oz”, “Svencoolie” y “Caleb Chilliams”.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-550000" name="module-550000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>“Chance the Scraper” recibió una mención honorífica después de terminar apenas .24% atrás de los seis primeros, según un comunicado de prensa de la ciudad.</p><p>“Quiero agradecer a la gente de Chicago por su creatividad incomparable, sentido del humor y orgullo cívico”, dijo el alcalde Brandon Johnson en un comunicado. “Estamos agradecidos e inspirados por la participación récord en el concurso de este año”.</p><p>Un número abrumador de habitantes de Chicago votó por “Abolish ICE” en las semanas previas al anuncio del lunes. Según una lista de todas las propuestas <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/01/snowplow-name-contest-streets-sanitation-ice" target="_blank" >proporcionada al Sun-Times</a>, el eslogan había sido ingresado aproximadamente 9,300 veces a finales de enero, representando aproximadamente el 70% de las propuestas. Otras propuestas, como “ICE out of Chicago” (“ICE fuera de Chicago”), también fueron nominadas.</p><p>Johnson también <a class="Link" href="https://x.com/ChicagosMayor/status/2001735382879113306" target="_blank" >sugirió</a> el nombre de “Abolish ICE” en redes sociales.</p><p>Después de que Chicago fue blanco de manera intensiva durante el Operativo Midway Blitz, la agresiva campaña de deportación de la administración de Trump el otoño pasado, relacionar el nombre de la quitanieve con el sentimiento anti-ICE se convirtió en una forma para que los habitantes de Chicago respondieran contra el Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS)</p><p>En enero, Johnson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/01/26/pritzker-y-johnson-piden-abolir-a-ice-tras-el-segundo-tiroteo-fatal-por-parte-de-agentes-en-minneapolis" target="_blank" >pidió abolir ICE</a> después de que agentes federales dispararon y mataron al enfermero de veteranos Alex Pretti en Minneapolis.</p><p>El lunes, Lauren Bis, subsecretaria adjunta de DHS, que supervisa ICE, citó un aumento en los asaltos contra oficiales de policía en una declaración y dijo, “los ataques y la demonización de ICE son incorrectos”.</p><p>Y añadió, “En lugar de demonizar a nuestras fuerzas del orden, deberían agradecer a nuestros agentes por quitar amenazas a la seguridad pública de las calles”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green

entries.title: Pet surrender surges during hard economic times — but there is a right way and a wrong way to do it.
entries.summary: <p>The black Kia rolled up shortly before midnight to <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/6/18/23765094/cats-resue-feral-animals" target="_blank" >Fat Cat Rescue,</a> a 7-acre haven for feral cats in Wadsworth that readers might remember visiting in the summer of 2023.</p><p>It certainly was not summer now, but late January and bitterly cold.</p><p>A couple got out of the car. You see them on security camera footage, jiggling locked door handles. They notice the doggie door., remove a cat from the car, push it through the door, then speed off.</p><p>Being a cat, however, the animal didn't stay where it was put. She ran back outside, into the freezing weather, joined by two more cats dropped off by the same couple.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-7a0000" name="module-7a0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Opinion bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Opinion</h2></div> </div><p>The volunteers who keep Fat Cat humming eventually corralled the three cats, one badly hurt by frostbite. Then they appealed to me.</p><p>"We need your help please," Michelle Andrich, a volunteer wrote. "Two-part help."</p><p>The first part was to share photos of the couple dropping off the cats and their car in the hope that "someone will recognize them and turn them in... There should be consequences for their actions."</p><p>Pass. In the annals of unpunished crime, dropping off cats at a shelter doesn't cry out for justice The couple didn't know any better, which leads to Fat Cat's second request.</p><p>"There are proper ways for a pet owner to surrender their pets," said Andrich. Would I help "educate or enlighten people on proper ways to surrender your pet"?</p><p>Well, I can <i>try</i>.Whether they actually get enlightened is on them.</p><p>People give up their animals for a variety of reasons — they move, lose jobs, can no longer afford their upkeep. Pets get sick, or their owners do. </p><p>What should you do if you can no longer care for an animal?</p><p>Start by planning ahead, if possible.</p><p>"Don't wait until the last minute," said Kaye Larsen Olloway, who runs Fat Cat and suggests giving at least a month to find your pet a home. "If you know you're moving out, don't wait until the night before to make arrangements for the pet. Give us a chance to make arrangements . We have a list of 20 other rescues we can contact."</p><p>Or reach out to Chicago Animal Care and Control.</p><p>"Our staff will help you," said Armando Tejeda, public information officer at CACC. "You don't have to do this alone. Resources exist."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/money/2025/07/25/pet-owner-surrender-dogs-cats-overwhelming-shelters-rescues" >Pet owner surrender rates are up, overwhelming Chicago shelters</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Tejeda said CACC will work with pet owners to help them keep their animals.</p><p>"If you just need food for a week or two, we can help you with that," said Tejeda. "Or minor surgery. The landlord won't allow unfixed animals, and you can't afford to neuter, we'll do the neutering, or bring your pet up to date on vaccines."</p><p>Business is booming at CACC — 5,753 pet surrenders last year.</p><p>"Last year our adoptions are the highest in our history," said Tejeda. "We're averaging 56 animals a day coming into the shelter."</p><p>Why the big jump?</p><p>"Housing instability is a big one right now," said Tejeda. "Landlords are telling tenants they can't have pets, or are imposing monthly fees — $25 to $50 a month or more. The rising cost of veterinary care is also a huge factor."</p><p>Pet owners have a far better chance of finding a home for an animal than CACC does.</p><p>"You're the best advocate for your pet," said Tejeda, pointing out that dogs get lost in the crowd at the shelter. "They shut down and are hard to show. All these dogs don't get out of the cage much. They're jumping up, barking."</p><p>Of course, CACC is a kill shelter — animals are put down, sometimes on the day they arrive.</p><p>"We should be a last resort," said Tejeda.</p><p>Although — and I'm pointing this out because people might not think of it — another reason pets are abandoned is because they're dying, and the CACC way is quicker and more merciful than freezing to death on the side of the road.</p><p>"We do offer low cost euthanasia, if someone knows it's time," he said. "A $10 charge."</p><p>Since people will ask, I'm happy to report the three cats abandoned in January at Fat Cat are doing well. They have names (the one with the worst frostbite is Elsa, for obvious reasons). They were lucky. You can help your pets be lucky too, if you remember the love you felt when you first got them should it become necessary to part ways.</p><p>"Dumping them is wrong whether you dump them at a rescue or dump them on the side of the road," wrote Andrich. "It’s just wrong. They are not garbage. The animals deserve better. If you can’t take care of them, then make an effort to find a place that can take them. Do the right thing."</p>
entries.author: Neil Steinberg

entries.title: Formula One arcade with racing simulators to open in River North
entries.summary: <p>A Formula One arcade with racing simulators is headed to River North.</p><p>The F1 Arcade is slated to open this summer at 1 W. Grand Ave., the former home of Rock Bottom Brewery that was a favorite among tourists and beer fans before it closed suddenly in 2023.</p><p>The Chicago location is the ninth F1 Arcade, with the first one opening in London in 2022. The first U.S. location opened in Boston in 2024. Other U.S. locations have recently opened in Washington, D.C., Philadelphia, Denver, Las Vegas and Atlanta. </p><p>The U.K.-based F1 Arcade, whose U.S. operations is based in Chicago, holds an exclusive Formula One license. Adam Breeden, co-founder of several entertainment venues such as Puttshack and Flight Club, founded F1 Arcade in 2021. </p><p>Chicago's location will be the first to have a rooftop terrace, as well as Chicago-inspired specialty cocktails and a dining menu, according to the company. There will be 70 full-motion racing simulators with multiple game modes, allowing guests to race individually or in teams.</p><p>Visitors will also be able to attend official Formula One watch parties.</p><p>"Chicago is a city that thrives on energy, competition and unforgettable experiences, which makes it a natural home for F1 Arcade,” Jon Gardner, president of global development at F1 Arcade, said in a news release. "With our U.S. headquarters based here, bringing F1 Arcade to River North feels especially meaningful. … This venue is designed specifically for the city and its culture.”</p><p>F1 Arcade plans to open 30 locations globally in the next five years, according to a news release.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a entries.title: Andrew Bird will make his Chicago Symphony Orchestra debut in November
entries.summary: <p><a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/2024/05/28/andrew-bird-jazz-album-chicago" target="_blank" ><u>Andrew Bird</u></a>, the multi-instrumentalist indie artist from the northern suburbs, will make his debut with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra this fall, the company announced Tuesday.</p><p>The performances this fall will celebrate the 20th anniversary of the release of Bird’s acclaimed album “The Mysterious Production of Eggs.” The pair of performances will take place Nov. 13-14 at Downtown’s Symphony Center. It will mark Bid’s first time performing the album in its entirety alongside a full orchestra.</p><p>According to the CSO, “the program balances swelling sounds with jazz, folk, and pop melodies.” Following a performance of the full album with orchestra arrangements, Bird, a Lake Forest native, will also play other fan favorites from his decades-long career.</p><p>Since the late ’90s, Bird has released 18 albums and earned a Grammy nomination for Best Folk Album for his 2019 release, “My Finest Work Yet.” In Chicago, his holiday season Gezelligheid concerts have become a local tradition and an often hard-to-get ticket.</p><p>While this is Bird’s debut with his hometown orchestra, he is no stranger to classical music halls. The violinist has performed shows in iconic venues like New York’s Carnegie Hall and Sydney Opera House.</p><p>Bird’s collaboration with the CSO comes after local rocker Billy Corgan, of Smashing Pumpkins, <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/music/2025/11/18/billy-corgan-smashing-pumpkins-night-of-mellon-collie-infinite-sadness-lyric-opera" target="_blank" ><u>teamed up last fall</u></a> with Chicago’s Lyric Opera to celebrate the 30th anniversary of “A Night of Mellon Collie and Infinite Sadness.” Plus, the Chicago Philharmonic teamed up with <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/music/2024/08/01/laufey-lollapalooza-chicago-philharmonic-orchestra-performances" target="_blank" ><u>pop-jazz superstar Laufey</u></a> in 2024 for what was billed as the first orchestral performance at Lollapalooza.</p><p>Tickets for Bird’s appearances at CSO will go on sale to the general public at 10 a.m. on Friday, March 20.</p><p><i>Courtney Kueppers is an arts and culture reporter at WBEZ. </i></p>
entries.author: Courtney Kueppers | WBEZ

entries.title: Fire hosting Tuesday groundbreaking ceremony for new stadium
entries.summary: <p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/fire" >Fire</a> have waited a long time for an event like the one they’ll hold next week.<br> <br>The club confirmed it will host a groundbreaking ceremony Tuesday at the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/fire/2025/09/25/chicago-fire-city-council-approval-south-loop-stadium-the-78" >site of the new stadium at The 78.</a> Running from 2-4 p.m., the event’s speakers will include Mayor Brandon Johnson, Ald. Pat Dowell, Fire owner and chairman Joe Mansueto and team president Dave Baldwin. Current coach and director of football Gregg Berhalter will be in attendance, as will Fire alumni and other guests.<br> <br>The groundbreaking comes more than two years before the stadium will see Fire matches. The team expects the facility to be ready in time for the beginning of the 2028-29 season, the second season in which MLS will play from late summer to spring instead of using the spring to fall format it had followed since its inception.<br> <br>That shift signals a giant change for MLS, and the new stadium represents another transformation for the Fire under Mansueto. <br> <br>Mansueto, who is bankrolling the 22,000-seat stadium, moved the Fire from SeatGeek Stadium in Bridgeview back to Soldier Field for the 2020 season. The Fire also officially opened a new performance center last year, and in 2025 made the playoffs for the first time since 2017 while showing a willingness to spend on top players and staff.<br> <br>The stadium issue, however, is one that has plagued the club for much of its existence. <br> <br>The Fire were displaced during the Soldier Field renovations and spent all of 2002 and most of 2003 in Naperville, playing at a temporarily expanded small college football stadium. In 2006, the team went to the soccer-specific stadium in Bridgeview, where the team declined on the field and that coincided with the struggles to draw urban fans to the southwest suburb. <br> <br>In 2019, Mansueto and the Fire paid $65.5 million to alter their lease with Bridgeview and return to Soldier Field immediately. But as soon as that move was confirmed, speculation began about whether the Bears’ home would be the Fire’s actual long-term dwelling or just a stopover.<br> <br>On Tuesday, the Fire will take another step toward building that permanent residence.</p>
entries.author: Brian Sandalow

entries.title: Cook County contractor: Pappas abused, bullied executives in profane ‘tirades’
entries.summary: <p>The chief executive of a major Cook County contractor alleged longtime county Treasurer Maria Pappas repeatedly subjected company executives to bullying, threats and “obscenity-filled tirades,” according to a copy of a letter obtained by WBEZ.</p><p>For months, Pappas has blamed Texas-based Tyler Technologies for technological problems that delayed property tax revenue payments to school districts, local governments and other taxing bodies across the county.</p><p>But in a letter Monday to Pappas, Tyler CEO H. Lynn Moore Jr. bemoaned what he called the “scapegoating” of the company, which has been working for years to upgrade the county’s property tax system. Moore alleged that the treasurer has shown a “lack of accountability” for mistakes by her own office in her efforts to “deflect blame and divert attention to us.”</p><p>The focus of much of the letter, though, was on Pappas’ behavior toward Tyler team members, who Moore said had faced “attacks” from the treasurer in the past year. Moore said the situation finally prompted him to conclude that Tyler executives would stop taking calls from Pappas and would not meet with her in-person again.</p><p>Moore said Tyler had reported on their interactions with Pappas to other county officials, including an aide to county Board President Toni Preckwinkle, only to hear “other County leaders minimize your conduct as ‘that’s just Maria being Maria.’”</p><p>Moore told Pappas, “You have berated and bullied my earnest and hard-working team members without repercussions or reproach, and you have tried to sabotage this project, for the last time. Others at Cook County may have grown accustomed to your approach and consider this business as usual, but I most certainly do not.”</p><p>Moore sent copies of the 9-page letter to Preckwinkle’s office and to the county board.</p><p>On Tuesday, Pappas did not immediately respond to questions about the letter from WBEZ.</p><p>But Preckwinkle said in a statement she took the accusations seriously and would forward the letter to internal watchdogs for the county.</p><p>“The alleged language and conduct directed at Tyler Technologies by the treasurer are troubling and unacceptable,” Preckwinkle said. “Public officials are expected to lead with integrity, demonstrate respect, and uphold the highest ethical standards, fostering public confidence in government.”</p><p>Preckinkle also said, “This matter will be formally referred to the Department of Ethics and Human Rights for a thorough review and any investigation deemed necessary.”</p><p>On Tuesday, Moore also did not respond to requests for comment, but the company sent WBEZ a brief written statement: “We believe the letter fully and clearly communicates our position.”</p><p>In his letter to Pappas, Moore detailed what he said were a series of threats, insults and other verbal abuse by the treasurer directed at Tyler’s project manager in Cook County, another employee on the project and one of the company’s “most senior executives.”</p><p>In May 2025, Moore wrote, Pappas told the unnamed project manager for Cook County that another Tyler executive was “the biggest f–k-up I’ve ever seen” and she “screamed” that she would “make sure he never gets another motherf—-g contract in the world ever again.”</p><p>Moore alleged that at a meeting last spring Pappas, in front of “multiple witnesses,” berated Tyler employee Mark Hawkins: “You stood over him, thrust your finger in his face, and unleashed a torrent of insults and threats.”</p><p>Moore wrote that Pappas more recently directed her “vitriol” at another Tyler executive, Abby Diaz. During a phone call around Christmas, Moore alleged, Pappas “insulted in colorful and sometimes racial language President Preckwinkle, the Bureau of Technology and its leaders, and the County Clerk.” Preckwinkle and Clerk Monica Gordon are Black. Pappas is Greek-American.</p><p>Moore also accused Pappas of calling Diaz a “token Hispanic.”</p><p>“You characterized her perceived lack of pushback with local media as ‘a 13-year-old getting raped who just says thank you,’” Moore wrote to Pappas.</p><p>Moore said Pappas called Diaz last week and told her: “You’re a f—-g idiot. Can you speak English? Learn to speak English. I’m going to ruin you.”</p><p>Moore told Pappas her “mistreatment” of Diaz “exceeds the bounds of human decency,” and had led him to take action.</p><p>“County leadership has not been able to insulate Tyler team members from your mistreatment or misinformation,” Moore wrote. “They say they do not control you, and insinuate that this type of abuse is almost a rite of passage. I do not control you either, but I am taking steps to protect my team.”</p><p>He said any communication from Pappas would be forwarded to him and that only he and company lawyers would respond. Moore also said Tyler’s entire team on the Cook County project would be working from home this week “as I do not feel comfortable having them onsite in the days following your receipt of this letter.”</p><p>Moore also alleged that Pappas “claimed to have been ‘feeding’ information to President Preckwinkle’s primary opponent, Ald. Brendan Reilly (42nd), about the Tyler contract.”</p><p>Reilly is running to unseat Preckwinkle in the March 17 Democratic primary, and he has criticized the incumbent over the county’s problems with the computer upgrade project. Reilly has said he would consider <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/government-politics/elections/2026/02/16/cook-county-board-president-march-democratic-primary-toni-preckwinkle-brendan-reilly" target="_blank" ><u>terminating the county’s contract</u></a> with Tyler, if elected.</p><p>Reilly spokesman Phil Swibinski said Tuesday everything Reilly has said about the topic has been drawn from media reports and the campaign’s own review of the Tyler contract.</p><p>“There’s nothing that came from Maria Pappas whatsoever, ” Swibinski said.</p><p>He added that the letter from Moore “was just an attempt to deflect blame from Toni Preckwinkle. She’s the one who failed here.”</p><p>Pappas has been the Democratic treasurer since 1998. She is running unopposed in the primary for what would be her eighth term but has said she <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2025/11/18/cook-county-treasurer-maria-pappas-mayoral-campaign-chicago-brandon-johnson" target="_blank" ><u>intends to run for mayor</u></a> next year.</p><p>The delays in property tax payments have proven costly to all kinds of public units of government, especially Chicago Public Schools and suburban school districts. The technological problems were <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/12/19/property-tax-payment-delay-costs-chicago-public-schools-almost-a-quarter-million-dollars-a-day" target="_blank" ><u>costing CPS about $250,000 a day</u></a>, and Pappas said in December her office had taken <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/12/26/cook-county-property-tax-maria-pappas-tyler-technologies" target="_blank" ><u>“emergency steps”</u></a> to distribute some of the unpaid revenue, which was several months behind schedule and totaled $8 billion at one point.</p><p>“That’s simply unacceptable,” Pappas said in a statement at that time. “Local governments shouldn’t have to worry about their cash flow because a vendor after more than a decade of work has failed to deliver a working system.”</p><p>Injustice Watch and the Chicago Tribune reported last year that three Cook County and state of Illinois agencies have paid Tyler a total of <a class="Link" href="https://www.injusticewatch.org/judges/court-administration/2025/costs-triple-delays-mount-in-tyler-technologies-contracts/" target="_blank" ><u>about $250 million</u></a> for technology upgrade efforts that have suffered from lengthy delays and big cost overruns.</p><p><i>Dan Mihalopoulos is a reporter for WBEZ.</i></p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/12/26/cook-county-property-tax-maria-pappas-tyler-technologies" >Cook County distributing $2.3 billion in property tax revenue amid long delay due to computer issues</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/12/19/property-tax-payment-delay-costs-chicago-public-schools-almost-a-quarter-million-dollars-a-day" >Property tax payment delay costs CPS almost a quarter million dollars a day</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2025/11/18/cook-county-treasurer-maria-pappas-mayoral-campaign-chicago-brandon-johnson" >Cook County Treasurer Maria Pappas says she’s running for mayor. She’ll leave it at that for now.</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Dan Mihalopoulos | WBEZ

entries.title: Bears GM Ryan Poles must set aside attachment as he eyes potential upgrades to roster
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> spent years pining for a season like the one they just had, and it was worth celebrating going 11-6 and winning a playoff game.</p><p>That was indisputable progress, but no serious organization is satisfied with merely that. The Bears dug themselves out of futility. Great. But there’s so much more to chase.</p><p>“We don't confuse the postseason victory or exceeding expectations from outside of the building [as it’s] OK to be complacent,” coach Ben Johnson said Tuesday at the NFL Scouting Combine. “It's not. We didn't do enough. We’ve got to do more.”</p><p>If they want to do better, they’ll have to be better. The same roster, even with projected improvement by quarterback Caleb Williams, theoretically would deliver the same outcome.</p><p>That means Johnson and general manager Ryan Poles must detach themselves from players they love, who just helped the Bears have their best season since 2018, and be ruthless in evaluating potential upgrades.</p><p>Poles and Johnson face decisions on pending free agents like safeties Kevin Byard and Jaquan Brisker and outside free agents, as well as what to do with the No. 25 overall draft pick, but they also have several key players under contract for next season that are up for discussion because of affordable escapes in their contracts.</p><p>That group includes linebacker Tremaine Edmunds, tight end Cole Kmet and running back D’Andre Swift. The Bears also could save salary-cap space by trading wide receiver DJ Moore.</p><p>Poles dodged a question about Edmunds’ future, left options open with Moore and said he felt “pretty good” about retaining Kmet and Swift.</p><p>Edmunds is coming off a good season with 112 tackles, four interceptions and a fumble recovery, but the Bears need to clear salary-cap space to address more pressing needs like left tackle and pass rush. They can pay Edmunds $17.4 million this season or cut him for $2.4 million. It’s sensible to reallocate that money.</p><p>The Bears are a negligible $4.1 million over the cap going into the new league year March 11 and can clear more than that by restructuring some contracts. But they’ll have to dig deeper to create enough space to acquire a high-end pass rusher like Maxx Crosby or Trey Hendrickson.</p><p>As much as technology has sped up communication, there remains no substitute for in-person interaction. When the Combine pulls the league’s general managers and agents into close proximity for the week in Indianapolis, things start moving.</p><p>Raiders general manager John Spytek, for example, was careful in his public comments Tuesday about planning to keep Crosby, but that conversation could be a lot different at a steakhouse. That’s why Poles stopped short of saying concretely the Bears will hang on to Kmet and Swift.</p><p>“I feel pretty good about [them] being here, but... any new, unique opportunities that might pop up are usually going to pop up here,” he said when asked specifically about those two. “We’ll get back and sort it all out and make decisions, but I feel pretty good about those guys.”</p><p>Given that the Bears just had a top-10 offense for the first time since 2013 and Kmet ($11.6 million) and Swift ($8.8 million) have reasonable cap numbers for their positions, they’re good fits. Swift just had a career year with 1,087 yards and nine touchdowns and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/16/bears-rb-dandre-swift-hopes-he-convinced-team-to-keep-him-heading-into-final-year-of-contract" >told the Sun-Times recently he hopes that’s enough to convince the Bears he should stay</a>.</p><p>Moore is the trickiest puzzle. He was ultra-reliable his first two seasons with the Bears, putting up 2,330 yards and 14 touchdown catches despite the offense being a mess and the quarterbacks struggling, then slipped to career lows with 50 catches for 682 yards.</p><p>Poles and Johnson were adamant that Moore has been worth more than those statistics show.</p><p>“He was a guy we could count on,” Johnson said. “The versatility is something that screams at you. The intelligence screams at you and... just the toughness, the durability. A player like that is really, really valuable.”</p><p>That’s not the entirety of the debate. Having Moore is a positive for the Bears, but is he a legitimate No. 1 wide receiver on a team with championship aspirations? Will he play up to his $28.5 million cap hit, which is seventh among receivers?</p><p>That’s difficult to answer. It’ll also be difficult for another team to answer if it’s considering making an offer. And then the Bears would face the challenge of replacing him within their budget. They’d be better off betting on Moore, still just 28, bouncing back.</p><p>“We want him here,” Poles said. “We think highly of him. He’s a great teammate. He’s been productive consistently over the last couple years.</p><p>“I have nothing but great things to say about him, but this is the time that you have to look at all the different scenarios and see what can allow us to put the best team out there. He’s a guy we want here, but we have to look at all different scenarios.”</p><p>It’s painful, but it’s the right way to think. If the Bears aren’t content with what they did last season, they can’t be content with their roster. Some moves are more likely than others, but Poles should be willing to listen on almost anyone.<br></p>
entries.author: Jason Lieser

entries.title: Warm up on a cold day with fiery mapo tofu, one of Sichuan cuisine’s most iconic dishes
entries.summary: <p>Mapo tofu is one of Sichuan cuisine’s most iconic dishes. It consists of silky tofu bathed in a fiery, aromatic sauce that balances heat, numbing spice and rich umami flavor. Mapo tofu roughly translates to “pockmarked grandma's tofu,” which is named for the elderly Chengdu woman who created the dish in the 19th century.</p><p>The stew is traditionally made with soft tofu and ground beef or pork. A potent blend of hot chile oil, fermented broad bean paste (doubanjiang) and Sichuan peppercorns delivers heat and complexity to the fiery stew. Meanwhile, the peppercorns numb the tongue, which helps to temper the chile heat.</p><p>Doubanjiang is a classic sauce and a key ingredient in Chinese Sichuan cooking. The ingredients can be purchased at Asian markets, in well-stocked supermarkets and online. Once you have your ingredients assembled, the dish comes together within 30 minutes.</p><h3>Mapo Tofu</h3><p><b>Active time:</b> 25 minutes<br><b>Total time:</b> 25 minutes<br><b>Yield:</b> Serves 4</p><p><b>Ingredients</b></p><p>2 teaspoons Sichuan peppercorns<br>3 scallions, white and green parts divided, sliced<br>3 garlic cloves, grated<br>2 tablespoons finely grated peeled fresh ginger<br>1/2 cup chicken stock or water<br>2 tablespoons Chinese cooking wine (Shaoxing) or sherry<br>1 tablespoon dark soy sauce<br>2 tablespoons doubanjiang (Chinese spicy bean sauce)<br>1 tablespoon chile oil<br>2 tablespoons water<br>1 tablespoon cornstarch<br>1 pound medium-firm tofu, drained, cut in 3/4-inch cubes<br>2 tablespoons vegetable oil<br>4 to 6 ounces ground pork (or chicken or turkey)</p><p><b>Directions</b></p><p>Toast the peppercorns in a dry skillet until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Transfer to a mortar with pestle or a spice grinder and grind to a powder. Set aside 1/2 teaspoon and reserve the rest for serving.</p><p>Combine the white scallions, garlic, ginger and the 1/2 teaspoon peppercorns in a small bowl.</p><p>In a separate bowl, combine the chicken stock, cooking wine, soy sauce, doubanjiang and chili oil.</p><p>In small separate small bowl, whisk the water and cornstarch.</p><p>Bring a medium saucepan of salted water to a boil. Carefully add the tofu and simmer for 1 minute. Drain the tofu.</p><p>Heat the oil in a large skillet (or a wok) over medium-high heat until it begins to smoke. Add the ground meat to the skillet and stir-fry until it begins to brown, 1 to 2 minutes.</p><p>Add the white scallion mixture and stir until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add the chicken stock mixture and bring to a simmer. Add the tofu and gently stir to coat.</p><p>Stir in the cornstarch mixture. Simmer until the sauce thickens, stirring constantly, about 1 minute. Add half of the green scallions and remove the skillet from the heat.</p><p>Divide the stew between serving bowls. Serve garnished with the remaining green scallions and the reserved ground pepper.</p>
entries.author: Lynda Balslev | TasteFood

entries.title: Gov. JB Pritzker announces $100 million redevelopment of Pullman's Hotel Florence
entries.summary: <p>Developers of Pullman’s historic Hotel Florence and the surrounding area announced plans to create a “mind-blowing entertainment experience” that is mixed with history and a new hub for local artists to showcase their talents — all headlined by a “world class” music venue.</p><p>The roughly $100 million revitalization project will transform the nearly 145-year-old hotel within the Pullman National Historic Park into a boutique hotel with new restaurants. The hotel’s annex will be rehabilitated and a concert hall will be added in the old Pullman Factory across the street.</p><p>Construction is set to begin in March 2027, with its completion expected in late 2028.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-290000" name="image-290000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/70ef890/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbe%2F79%2F85fda17442fa8551e9e87923a786%2Fflorence-260225-004.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/cc07432/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbe%2F79%2F85fda17442fa8551e9e87923a786%2Fflorence-260225-004.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ee9ebf4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbe%2F79%2F85fda17442fa8551e9e87923a786%2Fflorence-260225-004.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Gov. JB Pritzker speaks from behind a podium about plans to redevelop the historic Hotel Florence in Pullman." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ee9ebf4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbe%2F79%2F85fda17442fa8551e9e87923a786%2Fflorence-260225-004.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8307b05/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbe%2F79%2F85fda17442fa8551e9e87923a786%2Fflorence-260225-004.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ee9ebf4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fbe%2F79%2F85fda17442fa8551e9e87923a786%2Fflorence-260225-004.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Gov. JB Pritzker speaks about plans to redevelop the historic Hotel Florence in Pullman.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“We are breathing new life into this incredible site, while preserving a treasured part of Illinois history,” Gov. JB Pritzker said Tuesday at an event announcing the project.</p><p>The Illinois Department of Natural Resources provided $21 million in funding, making the project the largest public-private partnership for the IDNR. The department issued a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2025/01/31/wanted-a-team-to-return-the-bloom-to-pullmans-historic-hotel-florence" >Request for Solicitations last year</a>, searching for a development team to revitalize the state-owned hotel at 11111 S. Forrestville Ave. and its 1914 annex.</p><p>The state has partnered with the Chicago-based development group Celadon Partners. Scott Henry, CEO of Celadon, said his family grew up and worked in Pullman, making this project personal.</p><p>He pointed to several similarities in Chicago and the U.S. between 1881, when Hotel Florence opened, and now. Chicago was on the heels of a pandemic, American politics were “chaotic” (President James Garfield barely won his election in 1881 and was assassinated soon after) and Pullman factories had revolutionized the city’s economy and advanced the railway industry.</p><p>Henry sees similar advancements happening in the Far South Side with the development of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/technology/2025/10/09/french-pasqal-us-headquarters-south-works-quantum-computing-park" >Illinois Quantum and Microelectronics Park</a>, about a 15 minute drive north of the Pullman National Historic Site. The neighborhood also has an Amazon distribution center and the Pullman Community Center, 10355 S. Woodlawn Ave. The CTA Red Line expansion project also plans to extend into Pullman.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-8b0000" name="image-8b0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/15729ff/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+625/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc3%2Fb8%2Fd31e253c4d3a81a7c6c8bacbc6d5%2Fflorence-260225-026a.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d1e42bb/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+625/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc3%2Fb8%2Fd31e253c4d3a81a7c6c8bacbc6d5%2Fflorence-260225-026a.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2175b3a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+625/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc3%2Fb8%2Fd31e253c4d3a81a7c6c8bacbc6d5%2Fflorence-260225-026a.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="The entryway of Hotel Florence" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2175b3a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+625/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc3%2Fb8%2Fd31e253c4d3a81a7c6c8bacbc6d5%2Fflorence-260225-026a.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/36df2d8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+625/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc3%2Fb8%2Fd31e253c4d3a81a7c6c8bacbc6d5%2Fflorence-260225-026a.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2175b3a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/8192x4598+0+625/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc3%2Fb8%2Fd31e253c4d3a81a7c6c8bacbc6d5%2Fflorence-260225-026a.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>The entryway of Hotel Florence</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Instead of our new guests coming here to buy Pullman cars, they’ll be treated to a mind-blowing entertainment experience in the former Pullman Factory,” Henry said. “I think of this area as becoming the beating heart of Pullman again. And if it’s going to be the beating heart of Pullman again, its soul certainly will be the Art of Culture.”</p><p>The arts organization Art of Culture is partnering with the developer to help bring talent and artists to the site's future music venue. Art of Culture CEO Heather Smith said the artistic hub only becomes Pullman’s “beating heart” because of the people it will attract.</p><p>“Art of Culture will really tap into our community and tap into what we know exists here today, and that’s the artistic energy of the South Side that sometimes needs platform and needs spaces to be highlighted,” Smith said.</p><p>She imagines a space buzzing with energy and art exhibitions, in addition to live music.</p><p>“We know it’s the vibration, the rhythm, the sounds that will come from Pullman, from this space that will be felt across the city,” Smith said.</p><p>Architecture firm Farr Associates is designing the project.</p><p>“We have a more intangible duty as architects, as designers, as historians to the translation of 150 years of cultural heritage and grassroots advocacy,” Mercedes Miley, president of Farr Associates and a Pullman resident, said.</p><p>Miley also requested residents to share with them any artifacts or photographs from past events at Hotel Florence.</p><p>“It’s a very well-documented site that as part of this project, we get to tell those stories again,” Miley said.</p><p>The hotel was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1969. It was saved from demolition when the Historic Pullman Foundation bought the hotel in 1975. The state purchased the building in 1991.</p><p>The hotel has been closed since 2000, with the exception of opening for occasional tours.</p>
entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: Jesse Jackson family invites five presidents, including Trump, to services honoring the civil rights leader
entries.summary: <p>Five American presidents, including President Donald Trump, have been invited to services next week commemorating civil rights leader and two-time presidential candidate Rev. Jesse Jackson in Washington, D.C., South Carolina and Chicago.</p><p>The U.S. Secret Service has already conducted a security sweep in anticipation of presidents in attendance at the House of Hope on the South Side, where a "People's Celebration" will be held Friday, March 6. The event is likely to be the largest and most star-studded among a week's worth of events. The Secret Service will also secure locations in Washington, D.C., where the family is planning to hold services next week, in anticipation of potential presidential and foreign leader arrivals.</p><p>The Jackson family has invited Trump and former Presidents Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, Joe Biden and George W. Bush to events commemorating him. It's unclear which events the presidents will attend. </p><p>The family on Tuesday said they had not received any confirmations of presidential arrivals, but anticipated them after a full schedule is released about services in both South Carolina and Washington. </p><p>Events are being held in South Carolina, where Jackson was born, and in Washington, D.C., to allow people to mourn Jackson. Details on the South Carolina and Washington events are still being finalized but will happen between March 1 and 5. House Speaker <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2026/02/20/house-speaker-mike-johnson-rev-jesse-jackson-family-request-lie-in-honor-us-capitol" target="_blank" >Mike Johnson last week declined a request</a> by Jackson’s family to have him lie in repose at the U.S. Capitol — but alternative Washington, D.C., locations were being discussed, including Howard University, the Washington National Cathedral or the National Museum of African American History.</p><p>Jackson will lie in repose Thursday, Feb. 26, and Friday, Feb. 27, at Rainbow PUSH’s Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m. A “People’s Celebration” in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. on Friday, March 6, at House of Hope at 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m. Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. Saturday, March 7, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity.</p><p>Trump was among top political leaders to extend his sympathies after Jackson’s death.</p><p>“I knew him well, long before becoming President,” Trump posted on his Truth Social account. “He was very gregarious — Someone who truly loved people! Despite the fact that I am falsely and consistently called a Racist by the Scoundrels and Lunatics on the Radical Left, Democrats ALL, it was always my pleasure to help Jesse along the way.”</p><p>Obama wrote in a statement with former First Lady Michelle Obama that Jackson "laid the foundation" for his own presidential campaign "to the highest office of the land."</p><p>"Michelle and I will always be grateful for Jesse's lifetime of service, and the friendship our families share," the Obamas said. "We stood on his shoulders." </p><p>Relatives of Jackson said that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/17/what-we-know-rev-jesse-jacksons-death-services" target="_blank" >“all are welcome,”</a> regardless of political party.</p><p>Jackson died at age 84 Feb. 17. He had been in declining health for a decade. In 2017 he announced he had been <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" target="_blank" >diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease</a> two years earlier, but last April he revealed that it was actually misdiagnosed progressive supranuclear palsy, a rare neurological disorder. He stepped down as president of PUSH in July 2023, citing health concerns. Jackson appeared onstage at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in August 2024, when he was presented to the crowd after a video celebrating his life, but he did not speak.</p>

entries.title: Stranded Chicagoans in Mexico now have options for flying home after cartel violence
entries.summary: <p>Chicagoans visiting Mexican cities that were jarred by cartel violence over the weekend have hope of returning home Tuesday as road blockages are cleared and airport operations resume.</p><p>The unrest in the state of Jalisco after the Mexican Army killed the leader of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, Nemesio Rubén Oseguera Cervantes, known as “El Mencho,” led to at least 48 hours of lockdowns and uncertainty.</p><p>Videos on social media showed foot and car traffic returning in some cities and towns on Tuesday as residents assessed damage and tourists made plans to leave.</p><p>The U.S. State Department confirmed late Monday that roads closed because of the violence — or blocked by cars burned by cartel members — were reopening, save for some between Guadalajara and the tourist town of Puerto Vallarta. Government officials also said multiple airlines had resumed operations at the Guadalajara and Puerto Vallarta airports.</p><p>Five flights to Chicago were among 100 canceled from Puerto Vallarta on Sunday and Monday after videos posted to social media showed chaos at the airports, according to the tracking website FlightAware.</p><p>A United Airlines flight from Puerto Vallarta left Monday afternoon and landed in Chicago in the evening. An airline spokesperson said full operations resumed at that airport and in Guadalajara on Monday.</p><p>American Airlines said it planned to resume its operations at both airports Tuesday with four extra flights between Puerto Vallarta and the United States with 750 additional seats. One American flight was scheduled direct to Chicago on Tuesday afternoon.</p><p>Both United and American travelers would be allowed to change their flights without charge to get back into the United States, the airlines said. AeroMéxico, VivaAeorbus and Volaris flights in and out of Guadalajara, including flights to the United States, were also operating normally Tuesday.</p><p>The State Department still advised Americans to seek shelter and minimize unnecessary movements, as well as to confirm that flights are on track for departure before heading to the airport.</p>
entries.author: Nader Issa
